commit_message:
Code cleanup in PXE driver

1. set_boot_device method not foreseen for PXE driver.
2. BaseException.message deprecated in Python 2.6

Change-Id: I486c0965cadf5e62016fa6cf09c4b9220e0e17d9

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-04 09:33:21.000000000', 'message': 'Fix delete_port definition

Some derived plugins may pass some extra arguments to the delete
port call, so the api should accept extra arguments

Change-Id: I94d4c1291d5103659fca19dcc7112dbb32f95c12
'}]
commit_message:
Fix delete_port definition

Some derived plugins may pass some extra arguments to the delete
port call, so the api should accept extra arguments

Change-Id: I94d4c1291d5103659fca19dcc7112dbb32f95c12

Just curious, I tried netaddr.IPNetwork("2001:db8:0:0:10:10:10:0/120") under Python 2.7 and didn't see an exception. Is this something particular to 2.6 or 3.3 (or did I do something wrong)?  If so, please indicate that in the commit message.'}, {'account_id': 2711, 'date': '2013-10-18 07:54:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2711, 'date': '2013-10-18 07:59:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

two inline comments'}, {'account_id': 2711, 'date': '2013-10-18 08:07:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

hi Paul, very thanks for your review,
yes, netaddr.IPNetwork("2001:db8:0:0:10:10:10:0/120") is ok, but it will be compressed into something like 2001:db8::10:10:10:0/120 after rendering by netaddr.IPNetwork.
unfortunately, the code uses "if (cidr != data):" to judge if it's a valid ipv6 address.
I have added the comment in the code based on Oleg's comment.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-18 08:50:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Do we need to support abbreviated CIDR format for IPv4?'}, {'account_id': 2711, 'date': '2013-10-22 14:29:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

Abbreviated ipv6 cidr like 2001:db8::10:10:10:0/120 is common, but abbreviated ipv4 cidr like 10/8 is not common.

Only speaking for ip address, rather than cidr, 2001:db8::10:10:10:0 is a valid and common ip address, I don't think 10 is a valid ip address as well.

So I tend not to support abbreviated ipv4 cidr. 
Of course, if there exists this special requirement in the future, I think we can file another bug to fix it.

Will, thanks for your review."}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-10-22 16:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2013-10-22 17:27:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-10-22 17:51:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Do not merge

This approach is not the direction we should take.  The proper fix follow this pattern:

>>> net = netaddr.IPNetwork('192.168.1.1/24')
>>> net.network == net.ip
False
>>> v6_net = netaddr.IPNetwork('2001:db8:0:0:10:10:10:0/120')
>>> v6_net.network == v6_net.ip"}, {'account_id': 2711, 'date': '2013-10-23 01:29:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 2711, 'date': '2013-10-23 01:31:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-17 15:02:04.000000000', 'message': 'Allow using ipv6 address without omiting zero

Now neutron support ipv6 address like 2001:db8::10:10:10:0/120,
but don't support ipv6 address without omiting zero
like 2001:db8:0:0:10:10:10:0/120
that will cause the exception "'2001:db8:0:0:10:10:10:0/120'
isn't a recognized IP subnet cidr, '2001:db8::10:10:10:0/120'
is recommended".

Change-Id: I755e38ea11c139e15488ec60e7d5682a244ab114

   '2001:0db8:0:0:1::1/128' or '2001::0:1:0:0:1100/120'

commit_message:
Support uncompressed ipv6 address and abbreviated ipv4 address

Now neutron supports zero-compressed ipv6 address like
'2001:db8::10:10:10:0/120' and unabbreviated ipv4 address
like '10.0.0.0/24'.
This path will make neutron also support uncompressed ipv6
address and abbreviated ipv4 address. for example:
1, uncompressed ipv6 address like 'fe80:0:0:0:0:0:0:0/128'
2, ipv6 address with multiple consecutive zero like
   '2001:0db8:0:0:1::1/128' or '2001::0:1:0:0:1100/120'
3, abbreviated ipv4 address like '10/24'

Change-Id: I755e38ea11c139e15488ec60e7d5682a244ab114
Closes-Bug: #1240790

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-28 15:09:39.000000000', 'message': 'db tests: replace assertEquals with assertEqual

In Python 2.6, both assertEqual and assertEquals are
convenience aliases to failUnlessEqual.

In Python 3, failUnlessEqual is explicitly deprecated.

This is part of blueprint assertequal

commit_message:
Install Guide: Move database section to main neutron.conf

The [database] section has been moved from the plugin files
to the main neutron.conf file for Havana. Follow this change
in all examples.

Also, tag controller with <replaceable> in Neutron chapter.

Change-Id: Ie231bca650e8aac929605238086c645443c5b4ba
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1247589
(cherry picked from commit 30b63304e6e70ab7f61707deedac0da97ab7be82)

commit_message:
change option "--token" to "--os-token"

Fixes Bug #1248525
In the 2nd paragraph of the document, it states "You can pass this with the --token option to the keystone", change the option to "--os-token".

backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1248525

Change-Id: I69bd61a43aec7b183ab8399dd44c6ab5cffa00f1
(cherry picked from commit 803df9fb44014853e2c51cc13cbd0d0197b19429)

'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-10-30 19:50:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I believe this will break if extra repos are being used. So at minimum it needs to check to see whether there are source lists for all registered repositories.

Note that offline is a soft offline - it tries to stay local but doesn't guarantee it, so while I like the intended improvements from this patch, I think it needs substantial work to meet the contract of 'offline'."}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-10-31 06:10:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hm, and I think adding external repositories is a) rare, b) something that is almost always succeeded by an update, and c) usually well after pre-install.d/03

I'm comfortable assuming that Ubuntu images have a working set of base source lists, and requiring that users do their own update after having introduced a need for it.

The only element I could find that does add a source before this runs was tripleo-staging, which installs a PPA, which we haven't updated in many many months."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-10-31 07:35:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Well the problem is that this patch introduces failure modes that --offline is not meant to have. It will mean that --offline becomes entirely unusable for people when that happens.

I'm delighted to see --offline support for apt become a thing, it's just that bringing it in with those failures modes seems super unwise to me, because it diminishes the predictability and thus confidence folk can have in --offline.

How many seconds is the update for you?"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-08 06:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-08 06:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

Whatever apt source lists are on the image will be sufficient and
will be more likely to hit local caches and thus not reach out to
the internet.

Change-Id: Ia21f9a6e3506c7caa71e6c3e3c55b8f4cd0a22e5
'}]
commit_message:
Do not run apt-get update in offline mode

Whatever apt source lists are on the image will be sufficient and
will be more likely to hit local caches and thus not reach out to
the internet.

Change-Id: Ia21f9a6e3506c7caa71e6c3e3c55b8f4cd0a22e5

commit_message:
Adds tests to test_servers_negative

This adds a negative test for
* pausing server of another tenant and
* resize a non-existent server.

Change-Id: Iba6c87963d23abe1126f8a04f5f0e7f313f53a68

commit_message:
Set Nova Scheduler to Depend on python-cinderclient

Nova Scheduler depends on the cinderclient python library.
However, it's Puppet file doesn't make it depend on the
cinderclient library, so when it is installed by itself
(i.e. as the only service on that particular node), the
scheduler service fails to start due to the missing libary.
This has now been corrected.

Fixes: bug #1246103
Change-Id: I23e7e429d663fc501c1c3e397f82b0496cf646e6

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-31 05:53:58.000000000', 'message': "Evacuate instance to a scheduled host

In the event of a unrecoverable hardware failure, support needs to
relocate an instance to another compute so it can be rebuilt. This
API call locates a suitable host within the same
cell (using nova-scheduler), and performs an update of the
instance's location to the new host (similar to a rebuild). This
call is only available to users with the Admin role.

Rebuild instances uses the task based workflow.
Compute api calls the conductor task api. Conductor used scheduler
to select destination if required. Else compute on the destination
host gets called.

blueprint find-host-and-evacuate-instance

Change-Id: I45147bb6818e9590831ae331cb43c2367f9c1c6f

commit_message:
Evacuate instance to a scheduled host

In the event of a unrecoverable hardware failure, support needs to
relocate an instance to another compute so it can be rebuilt. This
API call locates a suitable host within the same
cell (using nova-scheduler), and performs an update of the
instance's location to the new host (similar to a rebuild). This
call is only available to users with the Admin role.

Rebuild instances uses the task based workflow.
Compute api calls the conductor task api. Conductor used scheduler
to select destination if required. Else compute on the destination
host gets called.

DocImpact

blueprint find-host-and-evacuate-instance

Change-Id: I45147bb6818e9590831ae331cb43c2367f9c1c6f

[{'created': '2013-10-30 19:09:03.000000000', 'message': 'VMware: Change cluster_name from MultiStr to ListOpt

Currently, the vmware driver uses MultiStrOpt for the cluster_name.
Hence, we need to repeat cluster_name property in the config file.
It is easier to specify them as list of comma seperated values.

Change-Id: If571877fbffb79d90128e27c446447fb105e87c4
'}, {'created': '2013-10-30 22:23:58.000000000', 'message': 'VMware: Change cluster_name from MultiStr to ListOpt

commit_message:
VMware: Change cluster_name from MultiStr to ListOpt

Currently, the vmware driver uses MultiStrOpt for the cluster_name.
Hence, we need to repeat cluster_name property in the config file.
It is easier to specify them as list of comma seperated values.

DocImpact

Change-Id: If571877fbffb79d90128e27c446447fb105e87c4

[{'created': '2013-09-27 08:09:09.000000000', 'message': "Fix issues affecting vmware driver code coverage

The patch addresses three issues affecting the code coverage of
the vmware driver.

1. File permissions on some test files are incorrectly set to 744.
   The code covergae tool doesn't execute these tests.
2. Handling of a deffered object in a polling function.
3. Unused private methods in vmops file.

Fixes: bug #1231848
Change-Id: Ief45cefa929ef0386f9062afb567426d336153da

commit_message:
Fix issues affecting vmware driver code coverage

The patch addresses two issues affecting the code coverage of
the vmware driver.

1. Redundant use of events in a polling function affects coverage
tool to overlook code that is actually executed.
2. Unused private methods, other methods in vmops file have been
removed.

Closes-Bug #1231848
Change-Id: Ief45cefa929ef0386f9062afb567426d336153da

commit_message:
Moves system tests so they can be run by testr

System tests (tests depending on a live database, server, etc.)
are being consolidated into a new location.  They are also being
excluded by default when using testr.

Change-Id: Ib36b199c869ca402b82f20c5267681b2e3b08c47
Fixes-Bug: #1243392

commit_message:
Replaces assertEqual with assertTrue and assertFalse

In order to improve coding practices and be aligned to a standard,
self.assertEqual(...,True) statements where replaced with
self.assertTrue and self.assertFalse.

Change-Id: Ide0bcef3f552810a5a3946b3fd04376a54733fcb
Closes-Bug: #1230127

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-31 18:36:45.000000000', 'message': 'Adds Support for Havana Configuration File Format

Previously, all sections of configuraiton files used capital
letters, i.e. [VLANS].  In Havana, only the [DEFAULT] section is
in captial letters.  Without this patch, configurtion files contain
duplicate sections, one in lower case and the other in upper case.
This causes confusion with users and leads to misconfiguration.

Change-Id: I9de057f8f845417a74d48946f38e0601727959b1
'}]
commit_message:
Adds Support for Havana Configuration File Format

Previously, all sections of configuraiton files used capital
letters, i.e. [VLANS].  In Havana, only the [DEFAULT] section is
in captial letters.  Without this patch, configurtion files contain
duplicate sections, one in lower case and the other in upper case.
This causes confusion with users and leads to misconfiguration.

Change-Id: I9de057f8f845417a74d48946f38e0601727959b1

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 1669, 'name': 'Julien Danjou', 'display_name': 'jd', 'email': 'julien@danjou.info', 'username': 'jdanjou'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2813, 'name': 'Mehdi Abaakouk', 'email': 'sileht@sileht.net', 'username': 'sileht'}, {'_account_id': 2860, 'name': 'litong01', 'email': 'email4tong@yahoo.com', 'username': 'litong01'}, {'_account_id': 4491, 'name': 'Lianhao Lu', 'email': 'lianhao.lu@intel.com', 'username': 'lianhao-lu'}, {'_account_id': 5387, 'name': 'Andrew Melton', 'email': 'andrew.melton@rackspace.com', 'username': 'andrew-melton'}, {'_account_id': 7368, 'name': 'Thomas Maddox', 'email': 'me@thomasem.net', 'username': 'thomasm'}, {'_account_id': 7763, 'name': 'Alexei Kornienko', 'email': 'akornienko@mirantis.com', 'username': 'akornienko'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 7763, 'date': '2013-10-03 14:19:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

1) I think you should not modify .gitignore file in this patch since it's not related to the change.
2) You create events implementation/collection but you don't have proper indexes on this collection. Cause of this your implementation will not work well on high scale deployments. Carefully chosen indexes should be created to make frequent queries efficient."}, {'account_id': 5387, 'date': '2013-10-03 14:23:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2013-10-03 14:27:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

lgtm, but I agree with Alexei's comments. 

Shouldn't be a problem for a +1 once that's addressed. 

You can set a global gitignore in your local devenv to prevent .idea files creeping in."}, {'account_id': 7763, 'date': '2013-10-03 14:29:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Please see my previous comment. Method get_events is inefficient without proper indexes"}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-10-03 14:41:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

how often the events get searched and queried does not seem
to be certain at this point. having index certainly slows
down the recording process. Sometimes, having both insertion and retrieval optimized is really hard to balance. 
I think we probably should make Ceilometer recording process
as fast as we can, then for analysis and query, the data
probably should be moved to secondary system for number
crunching so that Ceilometer will ensure that the meters,
events will get recorded as fast as it can. I kept thinking
about very high volume systems which produce thousands of
meters per second.
Agreed to get rid of the .ignore file, was not sure why it
was added. On the index thing, probably wait until more
information is available, having index is not free.'}, {'account_id': 7763, 'date': '2013-10-03 14:52:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Tuning storage for maximum performance is indeed very complicated task.

For really big deployments that are many ways to optimize performance:
1) proper sharding (which again requires carefully chosen shard key)
2) Different indexes can be used on different members of replica sets: no indexes on master node + read indexes on slave nodes - such approach will allow to use slave reads.
But I think that such tuning is out of scope of default ceilometer settings.

I think that by default we should target medium sized deployment and for such storage index insertion time is negligible. on the other hand it will greatly improve selection queries.

We should at least have indexes on `generated` field since it's always present in queries + this will allow to sort results on the mongo server instead of python code."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-03 15:02:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGit#Test_Failures

- gate-ceilometer-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/48/49548/2/check/gate-ceilometer-pep8/f4d112c : SUCCESS in 1m 27s
- gate-ceilometer-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/48/49548/2/check/gate-ceilometer-docs/b0fb108/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 4m 11s
- gate-ceilometer-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/48/49548/2/check/gate-ceilometer-python26/c74917c : SUCCESS in 10m 13s
- gate-ceilometer-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/48/49548/2/check/gate-ceilometer-python27/be3ef71 : SUCCESS in 4m 11s
- check-tempest-devstack-vm-full http://logs.openstack.org/48/49548/2/check/check-tempest-devstack-vm-full/d22c7d0 : SUCCESS in 38m 07s
- check-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full http://logs.openstack.org/48/49548/2/check/check-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/0811471 : FAILURE in 30m 52s
- check-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron http://logs.openstack.org/48/49548/2/check/check-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron/c72442c : SUCCESS in 22m 39s
- gate-tempest-devstack-vm-large-ops http://logs.openstack.org/48/49548/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-large-ops/1aa0d38 : SUCCESS in 11m 43s
- check-swift-devstack-vm-functional http://logs.openstack.org/48/49548/2/check/check-swift-devstack-vm-functional/db886e9 : SUCCESS in 13m 03s
"}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2013-10-03 15:06:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Perhaps store the traits as 

key=<key>
value=<value>

and put a compound index on event_id.key.value
and a separate index on key and value so we can do a query like "get all events with host = 'foo'"

This is a little more clunky than breaking out each trait, but this would mean we'd have to put a separate index on each possible trait name. Not practical.'}, {'account_id': 5387, 'date': '2013-10-03 15:45:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I do like the idea of storing traits as key=x,value=y, but I do see one negative with that. While we get to define a large compound index on (traits.key, traits.value), we will lose the ability to define single indexes on things like traits.instance_uuid, traits.publisher, etc...

As for general indexes, I think one for generated and one for event_name should be sufficient. Index tuning for traits should be left to the deployer.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2013-10-03 16:02:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

True, but we're going to have hundreds of trait names. Do we really expect the operator to manage that?

Perhaps we should ship out of the box with the 90% covered?

host
image_type
cell
service
...
etc"}, {'account_id': 5387, 'date': '2013-10-07 17:40:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-07 18:20:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Looks good, but I don't like to have code used for testing purpose in the backends implementation.

Perhaps I'm wrong, but writing something through the storage API and then reading it , looks sufficient to test the storage driver from the storage API point of view.

In this case, we just need to ensure that tests in EventTest are covered by those in GetEventTest.

WDYT ?"}, {'account_id': 5387, 'date': '2013-10-28 19:30:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

@Mehdi, agreed, I'll get it removed and make sure we're covering everything in the GetEvents test cases.

After some initial testing with indexes on traits, I'm rethinking the structure for traits. Will report back once I've got results."}, {'account_id': 5387, 'date': '2013-10-29 18:21:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

@Mehdi: While I was removing the test code that made it into the SqlAlchemy implementation I found a bug that made it so SqlAlchemy couldn't return Events without Traits. I've pushed up the refactoring the removes the test code and fixes that bug here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/54392/"}, {'account_id': 5387, 'date': '2013-10-31 20:47:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 5387, 'date': '2013-10-31 20:48:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
python3: Fix traceback on python3

cmp keyword has been removed in python3, replace with python2/python3
compatible code.

Change-Id: Idb415a5b19176809b42c479f92878dd0d2216332
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
avoid changing the rule's own action

fixes Bug #1240812

When iterating through the rule list, we should not change the rule itself.
So that we can use the rule data for the second router.

Change-Id: I613438507949007bec41416e7f8530693e4d5129
(cherry picked from commit c8b07d52936c9cfea5784e0efca3bc86e4aba7cc)

Having a look at https://github.com/simplegeo/python-oauth2 the oauth2 library is based on httplib2. How does this affect our moving to requests and HTTPs cert verification?'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-08-21 00:25:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29:

Hey Jamie, the httplib2 part is only used if we opt to use the built in 'client' support that the library provides. 

The client (simplifying a bit here..) just signs and sends the request. We could remove calling the client and just sign the request and send it ourselves instead."}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-08-21 20:25:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 30.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2013-08-23 04:13:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I can't spot anything wrong with the code itself.

I'd prefer that you put this in a module within contrib so contrib.oauth.consumers rather than it the toplevel. 

Also as mentioned inline i'd like there to be a class in that module that simply holds the consumer and token object so on client you say 

self.oauth = contrib.oauth.OAuth(self)

which just inits the consumers and token modules and then later you access consumers as:

client.oauth.consumers.list()"}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-08-27 21:23:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32:

Re our IRC chat i like the idea of splitting the TokenManager. If access_token and request_token are such different things then there is no reason to share a manager just because they are token related

so client will have: 
client.oauth1.consumers
client.oauth1.access_tokens
client.oauth1.request_tokens
and list() etc will be for the appropriate manager."}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-09-26 17:58:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 42.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-26 23:07:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42: Works for me

commit_message:
html_body

Adds simple HTML rendering for keystone
This makes sense when viewing Keystone from a web browser.
Merges all of the content type processing into a single middleware component
with logical ordering of procesing for the types.

blueprint render-html

Change-Id: I09d5b782cba45c8ac51f21a68c1176a0df05bc41

Adding active tests for updating/replacing image members

Adding active tests for API:
PUT v1/images/{image_id}/members
PUT v1/images/{image_id}/members/{image_id}

Change-Id: I5475bb0b7b06fa3d907006a69d656408b0e03b22

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-09 09:41:45.000000000', 'message': 'Cleanup for Per-Domain-Identity

Perform a chunk of the cleanup needed for per-domain-identity
backends.  This includes ensureing that domain_scope is passed in
the relevant @domains_configured methods on the Identity Manager,
adding in a mechanism to extract the domain_id from the context
during the @protected decorator execution, among other bits of
refactoring.

If possible, domain_id was extracted from project/tenant that
was passed into methods that required it.

The assignment_api also saw some basic cleanup (continuation)
on doing lookups for users or groups against the identity_api.
This was to simplify the interactions for determining domain_scope
and were not-required as the controller already handled the
verification of the user/group against the identity_api.

This also handles cleaning up a couple domain related edge cases
that could trigger undesireable behavior. (e.g. delete_domain
not succeeding beyond deleting tokens/credentials for the
first user or group on a read-only LDAP backend).

This patchset is targeted to be the minimum required to get
the per-domain-identity-driver concept to an "expirimental"
stage (with some known issues).

Known issues (partial list):
* Many cross-domain scenarios do not work with multiple id
  backends. e.g. It is not possible to create a grant for a user
  in one domain (on a specific backend) for a project that is in
  a domain on a differing identity backend.

* There is no concept of a "cloud admin" or super-admin user with
  multiple identity backends.  A number of actions (e.g.
  delete_user) requires the "admin" user to be a member of the
  domain of the user that is to be deleted.

* All v2.0 Calls (intentionally) will only reference the
  configured default_domain.

* Authenticating by user_id only will not result in the correct
  domain to be used if the user is not in the default_domain's
  driver.  It is possible to pass in a domain element (similar
  to authenticating with user_name) that will be used to look
  up the correct identity backend.

partial-bug: 1218094
Change-Id: I73ac2d2db6e766efe6ebd41a4ad9a701b2fac7a3

commit_message:
Cleanup for Per-Domain-Identity

Perform a chunk of the cleanup needed for per-domain-identity
backends.  This includes ensureing that domain_scope is passed in
the relevant @domains_configured methods on the Identity Manager,
adding in a mechanism to extract the domain_id from the context
during the @protected decorator execution, among other bits of
refactoring.

If possible, domain_id was extracted from project/tenant that
was passed into methods that required it.

The assignment_api also saw some basic cleanup (continuation)
on doing lookups for users or groups against the identity_api.
This was to simplify the interactions for determining domain_scope
and were not-required as the controller already handled the
verification of the user/group against the identity_api.

This also handles cleaning up a couple domain related edge cases
that could trigger undesireable behavior. (e.g. delete_domain
not succeeding beyond deleting tokens/credentials for the
first user or group on a read-only LDAP backend).

This patchset is targeted to be the minimum required to get
the per-domain-identity-driver concept to an "expirimental"
stage (with some known issues).

Known issues (partial list):
* Many cross-domain scenarios do not work with multiple id
  backends. e.g. It is not possible to create a grant for a user
  in one domain (on a specific backend) for a project that is in
  a domain on a differing identity backend.

* All v2.0 Calls (intentionally) will only reference the
  configured default_domain.

* Authenticating by user_id only will not result in the correct
  domain to be used if the user is not in the default_domain's
  driver.  It is possible to pass in a domain element (similar
  to authenticating with user_name) that will be used to look
  up the correct identity backend.

partial-bug: 1218094
Change-Id: I73ac2d2db6e766efe6ebd41a4ad9a701b2fac7a3

commit_message:
Comply with new hacking requirements

With new hacking>=0.8.0,<0.9 requirements, some functions are
now deprecated.

assertEquals -> assertEqual
assertNotEquals -> assertNotEqual
assert_ -> assertTrue

Change-Id: If666b68e6af5fcb9565f10c645b4e13dca16a141

commit_message:
change option "--token" to "--os-token"

Fixes Bug #1248525
In the 2nd paragraph of the document, it states "You can pass this with the --token option to the keystone", change the option to "--os-token".

backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1248525

Change-Id: I69bd61a43aec7b183ab8399dd44c6ab5cffa00f1

removed duplicate 'quantum-server' services.

The service_names were the same thing. The ignore_failure is no longer necessary.

Change-Id: Ib9f0126ae9276a3cb9f88350ecce58b24e8fc9bb

commit_message:
Sync config file generator from oslo

This commit syncs in the sample config generator from Oslo-incubator.
This will enable the sample file to be auto generated instead of
managing it by hand which is prone to errors.

Partially Implements: blueprint config-cleanup

Change-Id: Ic2553da72de5978b5d721d2ddb4c68ec1bf5005d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-25 21:52:14.000000000', 'message': "Added `endpoints` recipe and attributes to support `bind_interface`

Added endpoints recipe to enable iterating over the contents of the
node['openstack']['endpoints'] hash and finding any non-nil `bind_interface` to
set the IP address. For example

    node['openstack']['endpoints']['identity']['bind_interface'] = 'eth0'

would set

    node['openstack']['endpoints']['identity']['host']

to whatever IP address was on 'eth0' rather than hard-code the IP addresses in
an Environment.

Change-Id: Ic07626d4e3b3fb743191077f95c5bdd04a5504cd
"}, {'created': '2013-10-28 17:52:21.000000000', 'message': "Added set_endpoints_by_interface recipe & attributes to support 'bind_interface'

commit_message:
Added set_endpoints_by_interface recipe & attributes to support 'bind_interface'

Added set_endpoints_by_interface recipe to enable iterating over the contents of
the node['openstack']['endpoints'] hash and finding any non-nil `bind_interface`
to set the IP address. For example

    node['openstack']['endpoints']['identity']['bind_interface'] = 'eth0'

would set

    node['openstack']['endpoints']['identity']['host']

to whatever IP address was on 'eth0' rather than hard-code the IP addresses in
an Environment.

Change-Id: Ic07626d4e3b3fb743191077f95c5bdd04a5504cd

I don't understand why this patch is necessary. The Keystone service catalog will return the image endpoint information. Authentication with Keystone will still need to occur when using the Glance CLI tool, so this isn't saving any roundtrip costs and IMO just makes the LWRP more confusing with an additional URI parameter."}, {'account_id': 26, 'date': '2013-10-28 16:56:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

If the image api service is not on 127.0.0.1:9292 the uploads don't work. My node[openstack][endpoints][image-api] are 10.0.0.12:9292 and I was getting this error:

Mixlib::ShellOut::ShellCommandFailed

Expected process to exit with [0], but received '1'
---- Begin output of glance --insecure -I glance -K openstack-image -T service -N http://10.0.0.12:5000/v2.0 image-create --name cirros --is-public true --container-format bare --disk-format qcow2 --location http://mom.lab.atx/isos/cirros-0.3.0-x86_64-disk.img ----
STDOUT:
STDERR: Error communicating with http://127.0.0.1:9292 [Errno 111] Connection refused
---- End output of glance --insecure -I glance -K openstack-image -T service -N http://10.0.0.12:5000/v2.0 image-create --name cirros --is-public true --container-format bare --disk-format qcow2 --location http://mom.lab.atx/isos/cirros-0.3.0-x86_64-disk.img ----

commit_message:
Use the image-api endpoint within the image_image LWRP for non-localhost uploads

Also updated the CLI glance usage to non-deprecated parameters. Immediate
service restart on the glance-api.conf template to catch updates to the
configuration.

Change-Id: I1f05bc367ccd06d2116e45f046897d9dff689f37

commit_message:
Super_admin_key role restriction and attrib fixes

* Do not role restrict super_admin_key in proxy config.  At one
point it was thought this may increase security by having the
super key only available on the management server, but this
is incompatible with some addon pipeline items like tempurl.
* Correct swauth_version attribute in proxy recipe which was
referenced incorrectly as swauth-version, leading to no swauth
installation action taking place
* Treat platform_options["swauth_packages"] properly as a
list which is how it is defined in attributes
* Further discoveries of swauth-source vs swauth_source
discrepancies corrected
* Cleanup guard check for swauth packages

Change-Id: Ia0579a4518f45f7a6d5602c22351361424134d85

commit_message:
Default region loading an old-style pickled ring

This is to support upgrades from swift < 1.8 using old-style pickled
rings to 1.10. Old-style pickled rings won't have region information.

Change-Id: I18b2acba3d346e41def9d25d3d4dbd12705e5375
Closes-Bug: #1248919

'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-11-06 18:10:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Okay, I see that there were cases in Keystone where coercion to a string type was necessary, so I'm good with doing that.  I'm still not sure I'm onboard with is_unicode though - is there any reason we can't always force message to be unicode?  We're going to blow up if someone passes us a non-string and doesn't explicitly tell us to convert to unicode (so the parameter is misnamed anyway, it should be convert_to_unicode or somesuch), and this is for logging so we don't need to be concerned about changing the type of the object we return - it's about to become text anyway.

tldr: I'd prefer to just do a "message = six.text_type(message)" right away and be done with it.  That way there's no chance of someone forgetting is_unicode and us throwing an exception on a log call.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2013-11-06 19:04:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-11-06 19:08:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Works for me

commit_message:
Add mask password impl from other projects

A couple of different projects have an implementation for 'masking'
passwords in logs and wsgi output.

This seems like something that should go into Oslo-incubator as a common
implementation. This implementation is based off the following two
implementations in Keystone and Nova:

  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26487/12
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/49664/

Partial-Bug: #1247217

Change-Id: I2b1bbb4d3ddaa163573b685b3e3a5e8a3977e390

commit_message:
Add TempHomeDir fixture which is already part of cookiecutter template

TempHomeDir fixture creates a temporary directory and sets it as $HOME in the
environment. Also tearDown will remove it and reverts back $HOME value to
the previous one.

1. In one of the review comments for https://review.openstack.org/#/c/55111,
   russellb suggested to add TempHomeDir fixture to test module.

2. Cookiecutter template for OpenStack based projects already has this.

Change-Id: I7bd86a9d1e1951e04a632cecb181fc1e2c30f392

commit_message:
early quorum responses

Allow the proxy to respond to many types of requests as soon as it has a
quorum.  This can help speed up responses (without changing the results),
especially when one node is acting up.

I had to fix a few unit tests that no longer match the backend http requests
made by our proxy.

Change-Id: Ieb070dc3019e217e717b96154a7a809409bf40a5

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-09-25 21:38:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-09-25 23:28:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I love it.  nom nom nom

But you know... there is not a *single* call to logger.info or logger.debug in ssync_sender or ssync_reciever - some statsd instrumentation or recon or something would also be very a welcome addition - we're all gunna want to have eyes on this once we start letting it peek out into the real world.  But we can take a stab that after it's merged if you don't have any notion of what might be some good places out of the gate off hand.

If you were thinking you might go ahead and mention sync_method in the deployment guide - i say go for it.  I like seeing it in the replication overview - it'd be nice to link from there to the relevant section in the deployment guide so adventurous folks know what bit to flip.  If you don't think it should be "advertised" you better go ahead and say so before I start twittering the death of rsync in swift 4EVA!

There's loads of tests.  Any particular reason coverage is so much better on the wsgi server side of REPLICATE vs. the replication daemon?  I stuck a NameError inside of a few methods on ssync_sender.Sender (e.g. updates, send_put, get_diskfile) and it didn't blow up anything ('cept good ol' probe tests :D).

p.s. going `chmod -x /usr/bin/rsync` and watching object replication still work is sorta awesome

p.p.s. don't try this with probetests tho, cause the account/container still needs it - guess my twitter campaign will have to wait.

Well done, sir.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-25 23:38:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

Finally, ssync is ready for its first real review! Sorry it took me the better part of a year to get to this point.

Not sure if SmokeStack will ever come back to post its report; but I won't worry about that for now. I probably wouldn't understand its output anyway. The errors I saw all seem to be the "usual" errors that don't result in a fail, except for something about a Torpedo failing; which basically tells me nothing.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-10-16 17:21:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (4 inline comments)

(saving inane review comments before hackathon lunch)'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-10-16 19:24:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: (2 inline comments)

Alright, so the semaphore is used to limit the number of concurrent replication requests per worker. (I looked at eventlet, and I didn't see any SysV semaphore stuff or anything like that; it looked to be all in-memory).

What about just using an instance variable on the object server? Like, self._current_replication_requests += 1 or -= 1. Seems like that'd be simpler (certainly less code), and the one behavior change is that a REPLICATION request would get an immediate go-away response, not one after 10 seconds or so, but that seems like it's probably okay."}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-10-16 19:46:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (3 inline comments)

(hackathon comments to duplicate what Greg is typing into his cellphone)'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-10-16 19:52:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Change-Id: If003dcc6f4109e2d2a42f4873a0779110fff16d6
"}, {'created': '2013-08-28 18:42:11.000000000', 'message': "SSync (RSync Alternative)

This is still a work-in-progress; but mostly I just have
more tests to write so I wanted to push this up for anyone
who'd care to start an early review. :)

SSync for this commit is just a direct replacement for how
we use RSync. Assuming we switch over to SSync completely
someday and drop RSync, we will then be able to improve the
algorithms even further (removing local objects as we
successfully transfer each one rather than waiting for whole
partitions, using an index.db with hash-trees, etc., etc.)

For easier review, this commit can be thought of in distinct
parts:

1)  New global_conf_callback functionality for allowing
    services to perform setup code before workers, etc. are
    launched. (This is then used by SSync in the object
    server to create a cross-worker semaphore to restrict
    concurrent incoming replication.)

2)  A bit of shifting of items up from object server and
    replicator to diskfile or DEFAULT conf sections for
    better sharing of the same settings. conn_timeout,
    node_timeout, client_timeout, network_chunk_size,
    disk_chunk_size.

3)  Modifications to the object server and replicator to use
    SSync in place of RSync. This is done in a generic
    enough way that switching to FutureSync should be easy
    someday.

4)  The biggest part, and (at least for now) completely
    optional part, are the new ssync_sender and
    ssync_receiver files. Nice and isolated for easier
    testing and visibility into test coverage, etc.

Change-Id: If003dcc6f4109e2d2a42f4873a0779110fff16d6

"}, {'created': '2013-10-13 18:04:12.000000000', 'message': "Object replication ssync (an rsync alternative)

For this commit, ssync is just a direct replacement for how
we use rsync. Assuming we switch over to ssync completely
someday and drop rsync, we will then be able to improve the
algorithms even further (removing local objects as we
successfully transfer each one rather than waiting for whole
partitions, using an index.db with hash-trees, etc., etc.)

For easier review, this commit can be thought of in distinct
parts:

1)  New global_conf_callback functionality for allowing
    services to perform setup code before workers, etc. are
    launched. (This is then used by ssync in the object
    server to create a cross-worker semaphore to restrict
    concurrent incoming replication.)

2)  A bit of shifting of items up from object server and
    replicator to diskfile or DEFAULT conf sections for
    better sharing of the same settings. conn_timeout,
    node_timeout, client_timeout, network_chunk_size,
    disk_chunk_size.

3)  Modifications to the object server and replicator to
    optionally use ssync in place of rsync. This is done in
    a generic enough way that switching to FutureSync should
    be easy someday.

4)  The biggest part, and (at least for now) completely
    optional part, are the new ssync_sender and
    ssync_receiver files. Nice and isolated for easier
    testing and visibility into test coverage, etc.

All the usual logging, statsd, recon, etc. instrumentation
is still there when using ssync, just as it is when using
rsync.

Beyond the essential error and exceptional condition
logging, I have not added any additional instrumentation at
this time. Unless there is something someone finds super
pressing to have added to the logging, I think such
additions would be better as separate change reviews.

FOR NOW, IT IS NOT RECOMMENDED TO USE SSYNC ON PRODUCTION
CLUSTERS. Some of us will be in a limited fashion to look
for any subtle issues, tuning, etc. but generally ssync is
an experimental feature. In its current implementation it is
probably going to be a bit slower than rsync, but if all
goes according to plan it will end up much faster.

There are no comparisions yet between ssync and rsync other
than some raw virtual machine testing I've done to show it
should compete well enough once we can put it in use in the
real world.

If you Tweet, Google+, or whatever, be sure to indicate it's
experimental. It'd be best to keep it out of deployment
guides, howtos, etc. until we all figure out if we like it,
find it to be stable, etc.

Change-Id: If003dcc6f4109e2d2a42f4873a0779110fff16d6
"}, {'created': '2013-10-25 01:49:20.000000000', 'message': 'Object replication ssync (an rsync alternative)

up and through Jenkins etc. for a sanity check.

we use rsync. Assuming we switch over to ssync completely

algorithms even further (removing local objects as we

experimental. It'd be best to keep it out of deployment

find it to be stable, etc.

4)  The biggest part, and (at least for now) completely
    optional part, are the new ssync_sender and
    ssync_receiver files. Nice and isolated for easier
    testing and visibility into test coverage, etc.

All the usual logging, statsd, recon, etc. instrumentation
is still there when using ssync, just as it is when using
rsync.

Beyond the essential error and exceptional condition
logging, I have not added any additional instrumentation at
this time. Unless there is something someone finds super
pressing to have added to the logging, I think such
additions would be better as separate change reviews.

FOR NOW, IT IS NOT RECOMMENDED TO USE SSYNC ON PRODUCTION
CLUSTERS. Some of us will be in a limited fashion to look
for any subtle issues, tuning, etc. but generally ssync is
an experimental feature. In its current implementation it is
probably going to be a bit slower than rsync, but if all
goes according to plan it will end up much faster.

There are no comparisions yet between ssync and rsync other
than some raw virtual machine testing I've done to show it
should compete well enough once we can put it in use in the
real world.

If you Tweet, Google+, or whatever, be sure to indicate it's
experimental. It'd be best to keep it out of deployment
guides, howtos, etc. until we all figure out if we like it,
find it to be stable, etc.

Change-Id: If003dcc6f4109e2d2a42f4873a0779110fff16d6
'}, {'created': '2013-10-30 17:54:06.000000000', 'message': "Object replication ssync (an rsync alternative)

NOT FOR REVIEW YET - Still working the diskfile-related
refactor. But getting closer.

For this commit, ssync is just a direct replacement for how
we use rsync. Assuming we switch over to ssync completely
someday and drop rsync, we will then be able to improve the
algorithms even further (removing local objects as we
successfully transfer each one rather than waiting for whole
partitions, using an index.db with hash-trees, etc., etc.)

For easier review, this commit can be thought of in distinct
parts:

1)  New global_conf_callback functionality for allowing
    services to perform setup code before workers, etc. are
    launched. (This is then used by ssync in the object
    server to create a cross-worker semaphore to restrict
    concurrent incoming replication.)

2)  A bit of shifting of items up from object server and
    replicator to diskfile or DEFAULT conf sections for
    better sharing of the same settings. conn_timeout,
    node_timeout, client_timeout, network_chunk_size,
    disk_chunk_size.

3)  Modifications to the object server and replicator to
    optionally use ssync in place of rsync. This is done in
    a generic enough way that switching to FutureSync should
    be easy someday.

4)  The biggest part, and (at least for now) completely
    optional part, are the new ssync_sender and
    ssync_receiver files. Nice and isolated for easier
    testing and visibility into test coverage, etc.

All the usual logging, statsd, recon, etc. instrumentation
is still there when using ssync, just as it is when using
rsync.

Beyond the essential error and exceptional condition
logging, I have not added any additional instrumentation at
this time. Unless there is something someone finds super
pressing to have added to the logging, I think such
additions would be better as separate change reviews.

FOR NOW, IT IS NOT RECOMMENDED TO USE SSYNC ON PRODUCTION
CLUSTERS. Some of us will be in a limited fashion to look
for any subtle issues, tuning, etc. but generally ssync is
an experimental feature. In its current implementation it is
probably going to be a bit slower than rsync, but if all
goes according to plan it will end up much faster.

There are no comparisions yet between ssync and rsync other
than some raw virtual machine testing I've done to show it
should compete well enough once we can put it in use in the
real world.

If you Tweet, Google+, or whatever, be sure to indicate it's
experimental. It'd be best to keep it out of deployment
guides, howtos, etc. until we all figure out if we like it,
find it to be stable, etc.

Change-Id: If003dcc6f4109e2d2a42f4873a0779110fff16d6

commit_message:
Object replication ssync (an rsync alternative)

For this commit, ssync is just a direct replacement for how
we use rsync. Assuming we switch over to ssync completely
someday and drop rsync, we will then be able to improve the
algorithms even further (removing local objects as we
successfully transfer each one rather than waiting for whole
partitions, using an index.db with hash-trees, etc., etc.)

For easier review, this commit can be thought of in distinct
parts:

1)  New global_conf_callback functionality for allowing
    services to perform setup code before workers, etc. are
    launched. (This is then used by ssync in the object
    server to create a cross-worker semaphore to restrict
    concurrent incoming replication.)

2)  A bit of shifting of items up from object server and
    replicator to diskfile or DEFAULT conf sections for
    better sharing of the same settings. conn_timeout,
    node_timeout, client_timeout, network_chunk_size,
    disk_chunk_size.

3)  Modifications to the object server and replicator to
    optionally use ssync in place of rsync. This is done in
    a generic enough way that switching to FutureSync should
    be easy someday.

4)  The biggest part, and (at least for now) completely
    optional part, are the new ssync_sender and
    ssync_receiver files. Nice and isolated for easier
    testing and visibility into test coverage, etc.

All the usual logging, statsd, recon, etc. instrumentation
is still there when using ssync, just as it is when using
rsync.

Beyond the essential error and exceptional condition
logging, I have not added any additional instrumentation at
this time. Unless there is something someone finds super
pressing to have added to the logging, I think such
additions would be better as separate change reviews.

FOR NOW, IT IS NOT RECOMMENDED TO USE SSYNC ON PRODUCTION
CLUSTERS. Some of us will be in a limited fashion to look
for any subtle issues, tuning, etc. but generally ssync is
an experimental feature. In its current implementation it is
probably going to be a bit slower than rsync, but if all
goes according to plan it will end up much faster.

There are no comparisions yet between ssync and rsync other
than some raw virtual machine testing I've done to show it
should compete well enough once we can put it in use in the
real world.

If you Tweet, Google+, or whatever, be sure to indicate it's
experimental. It'd be best to keep it out of deployment
guides, howtos, etc. until we all figure out if we like it,
find it to be stable, etc.

Change-Id: If003dcc6f4109e2d2a42f4873a0779110fff16d6

subject: changed default values of OPENSTACK_ENDPOINT_TYPE to publicURL

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-05 21:11:19.000000000', 'message': 'Update the keystone configuration script for Barbican per Johns Hopkins team.

The Johns Hopkins team has been working to integrate Barbican in to their
encryption key management work flows. Hadi A. Esiely Barrera provided modifications
that were needed to the Barbican Keystone configuration script to make it
function correctly. This change request also restores the barbican-all script
as teams such as Johns Hopkins are utilizing it.

Change-Id: I764bd1606a0f8124660651104eb0dd58e82b9f6f
'}]
commit_message:
Update the keystone configuration script for Barbican per Johns Hopkins team.

The Johns Hopkins team has been working to integrate Barbican in to their
encryption key management work flows. Hadi A. Esiely Barrera provided modifications
that were needed to the Barbican Keystone configuration script to make it
function correctly. This change request also restores the barbican-all script
as teams such as Johns Hopkins are utilizing it.

Change-Id: I764bd1606a0f8124660651104eb0dd58e82b9f6f

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-11-05 00:03:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The behavior in 1.8.0 is a 403 w/body "Recently deleted".

In more detail, that looks like:

 * GET /v1/AUTH_bob: actually autocreates AUTH_bob
 * DELETE /v1/AUTH_bob
 * GET /v1/AUTH_bob: tries to autocreate AUTH_bob, but fails due to it being recently deleted, and returns the 403 from one of the account servers'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-11-05 00:19:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This works for me. I'm not particularly fond of a 403 as a response to a simple GET just because the account's in some wonky state; I think the 410 is nicer.

Although, if a 410 is for things that are permanently deleted, but the account may be recreated in the future, that makes me wonder if they're the same or not. If I delete /v1/AUTH_bob, wait a week, and create a new /v1/AUTH_bob, is that the same account as before? After all, It has the same URL, but a different underlying sqlite DB. If the Ship of Theseus falls on a mime in the forest, does anybody care?

Anyhow, I'll hold off on approving this change for a day or two to give others a chance to chime in."}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-11-07 16:50:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-11-07 22:21:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-11-07 22:21:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

commit_message:
Fix a typo in the name of logger method exception

LOG has no attribute Exception. Should be LOG.exception insetead
of LOG.Exception.

Change-Id: I217dac398ebeb4e289b9b171333c0898f00e4314

commit_message:
Install Guide: Move database section to main neutron.conf

The [database] section has been moved from the plugin files
to the main neutron.conf file for Havana. Follow this change
in all examples.

Also, tag controller with <replaceable> in Neutron chapter.

Change-Id: Ie231bca650e8aac929605238086c645443c5b4ba
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1247589

commit_message:
Updates WADL to include missing call GET /v2/images/{imageId}/members

Also made the API description more accurate since you can't actually
create images in Glance, only image records.

Change-Id: Iac2b41bbf62e869a2eee0ea265deb2e56314cde8
Closes-Bug: #1248395

commit_message:
Improve sample configs

1) Rename sample-task.json to sample-task-boot-and-delete.json to be more
   specific; also restructure it a bit to bring it into compliance with
   sample-task-soft-reboot.json;
2) Add sample-cloud-verification.json that shows how to use verification.

Blueprint rally-docs

Change-Id: I8fa4f92c74ec49d8637cba131c9cd309028dc73a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-31 23:16:05.000000000', 'message': "Don't label or format disks for Ceph OSDs

Along with the changes from this https://github.com/Mirantis/fuel/pull/773
we no longer need to label Ceph disks. This removes superflous mkfs calls during
post-intallation and works around issues in ceph-deploy and ceph-disk.
Closes-Bug: #1246513

commit_message:
Don't label or format disks for Ceph OSDs

Along with the changes from this https://github.com/Mirantis/fuel/pull/773
we no longer need to label Ceph disks. This removes superflous mkfs calls during
post-intallation and works around issues in ceph-deploy and ceph-disk.
Closes-Bug: #1246513

Change-Id: I91e6c253c164936c8b12798520cbd45587a36036

commit_message:
Debian consitency and links

This patch reviews the "Answer to the debconf" things in
every service, so that they look the same.

It also adds links to the debconf chapter, so that users
can navigate more easily in the doc.

It also changes the titles of the debconf chapter so that
they match the text in each chapter.

It also documents the fact that python-argparse should be
installed manually on all Wheezy setups, which is an issue
that has been reported by some users, and which wasn't
documented.

The patch also extends the explanations about the
meta-packages.

This patch adds a lot of <informalfigure> tags that were
missing as well.

Finally, the patch also moves the explanation about remote
MySQL setup from the nova installation procedure to the
debconf-dbconfig-common section of the debconf chapter,
which is a much better fit.

This is my last clean-up work, I believe.

Change-Id: I5a85f39e49786ae90cc0afbf13b94baf486408f4
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit f174fc2caab209061069621bfe26fb3edb75d6c7)

commit_message:
Refactor task updating flow in case of error and success

* if orchestrator reported that deployment
  task is ready, then all nodes should be
  in ready status, even if orchestrator
  didn't send statuses for this nodes
* if provisioning task failed, all nodes
  in provisioning status should be marked as
  error with error_type provision
* if deployment task failed, all nodes in
  status deploying should me marked as error
  with error_type deploy

PRD-2512
PRD-2381
PRD-2126

Change-Id: I0ce745dc393fdeca51b7190778c3c2d1ffccd23f

commit_message:
Ensure that L3 managed port have status ACTIVE

Some plugins may set the port status as DOWN when it is created. This was not
updated when the port was actually up. This patch ensures that gateway and
router ports that are created will be set as ACTIVE when they are actually
up and running.

Ports that are attached to additional bridges in the OVS will only update the
port status as ACTIVE. There will be no tags set on the specific ports as this
will break the existing functionality.

Fixes bug 1192883

(cherry picked from commit d88ea97228ec8bb38f071c3969fdbb3abf6ab575)

Conflicts:

	quantum/tests/unit/openvswitch/test_ovs_quantum_agent.py
	quantum/agent/linux/ovs_lib.py
	quantum/plugins/openvswitch/agent/ovs_quantum_agent.py
	quantum/tests/unit/openvswitch/test_ovs_tunnel.py

Change-Id: I9993f56963ac704f0f345102d2e8b2d99dd9ad9e

This patch changes list_resource_types() api function
to return a dictionary like {'resource_type': 'support_status'}
instead of returning a list of resource types.

Implements bp filter-resources-by-support

Change-Id: I0c4fe3416fa728e6415e0563c1ae99f5df25be0c
"}]
commit_message:
Change list_resource_types() to return resources and status

To implement bp filter-resources-by-support api
function which will return all available resources with
its support status is needed.

This patch changes list_resource_types() api function
to return a dictionary like {'resource_type': 'support_status'}
instead of returning a list of resource types.

Add changes to heat/tests/test_engine_service.py

Implements bp filter-resources-by-support

Change-Id: I0c4fe3416fa728e6415e0563c1ae99f5df25be0c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-07 13:14:44.000000000', 'message': 'Fix issues on CentOS.

1. On CentOS django 1.4.9 is used, that breaks new-style urls (full
support in django 1.5).

2. Also we have different murano-repository config on Fuel
installation, that also caused a bug due to hardcode in
murano-dashboard.

Change-Id: Ice4324c258330e790a51954c4ade58ba3fd7c6bc
'}]
commit_message:
Fix issues on CentOS.

1. On CentOS django 1.4.9 is used, that breaks new-style urls (full
support in django 1.5).

2. Also we have different murano-repository config on Fuel
installation, that also caused a bug due to hardcode in
murano-dashboard.

Change-Id: Ice4324c258330e790a51954c4ade58ba3fd7c6bc

commit_message:
nova security-group-* should support uuid as input

If we installed neutron, the security-group request will be handled
by neutron, however neutron is using uuid as key for security-group,
nova uses an int value as key, for current novaclient, it only
support the security-group which key is int, so will raise exception
for uuid input.

Change-Id: I8dedd58266c1182991b6ca24fefc0f220f8815d6
Fixes-Bug: #1247728

commit_message:
[PRD-2083] Run full check in verify_networks task

Now complete check_networks task will be executed within verify_networks task.
Only network configuration check was executed before that (w/o interfaces mapping check).

Closes-Bug: #1246297
Change-Id: Id424be1a22fb0a16ff8fd7300e96623dfb598306

'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-10-06 22:09:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I guess negative tests of *action* should be added to tempest/api/compute/servers/test_servers_negative.py."}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2013-10-07 02:54:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi, Ken'ichi, 

I noticed there is no consensus that where the negative tests should be. see tempest/api/compute/servers/test_servers.py. see Cores' opinion?"}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-10-07 03:03:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Lingxian,

I know. and I am starting to fix it. (If3ddb2a0a5d27a87d610c6d8e7783d400fd32606)

Most negative tests of server "action" are written on test_servers_negative.py. so I feel the test cases what are added by this patch should be done.'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2013-10-07 09:19:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Ken'ichi:

I think there are too many kind of operations in one negative.py. On the contrary, I think tests of one action should stay in one file, including both positive and negative tests."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-10-07 09:24:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Lingxian,

I can see your opinion, this my -1 is soft one.

This patch is a good chance for making a consensus of this topic. So let's wait for other opinions :-)"}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2013-10-07 13:27:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I actually agree with Lingxian on the idea that we may probably get rid completely of the _negative.py and stick with the "negative" attribute'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-10-07 13:47:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

We have many test cases related to servers and the negative and non negative tests already mixed in many places.

These are action related tests, they can be in this file.

I have no idea what is the good balance of the server test cases files, so I do not think it really worth now spending time on discussing the proper distribution.

test_server_actions is 326 line, imho it is not too big.

May be creating a test file for negative actions (and moving some action related negaitve tests) wouldn't be a bad idea.

I do not recommend to mix test case re-org and new test addition type of change into one change-set.

By keeping the negatives in the test_server_action we can save one server creation operation.

IMHO now these test cases can be added to this file, and we can discuss  the proper location related to a reorg change-set."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-10-07 15:14:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Hi afazekas, Giulio,

Thanks for your comments, now I see that this patch should not change all negative action tests to test_server_actions.py or test_server_negative.py.'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-10-08 02:34:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Why don't you add positive tests for force_delete/restore?"}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2013-10-08 03:07:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

hi, Masayuki:

Because we can only force_delete a 'soft-deleted' server, and a server can be soft-deleted only if the 'reclaim_instance_interval' item is set(default is 0)."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-10-08 05:50:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-10-08 13:51:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
add some negative tests for force_delete/restore

- test_force_delete_nonexistent_server_id
- test_force_delete_server_invalid_state
- test_restore_nonexistent_server_id
- test_restore_server_invalid_state

negative tests should stay in negative files of corresponding action.

Change-Id: Icafcb1e17382f8856937e8e903650fb424b00a25

commit_message:
Option for installing spice-html5 and novnc from packages

The novnc and spice-html5 is installed from git repository by default,
but not from an openstack* repository.

In order to add vnc/spice proxy related gating tests they should be installed
from packages.

New boolean variables added to control the installation source:
NOVNC_FROM_PACKAGE and SPICE_FROM_PACKAGE

Related changes:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/51790/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/50822/

Change-Id: I1e55fd99edd30876924a13160afb74ff3e97c485

commit_message:
Rename libvirt flags to more sane names

Now that the flags in nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py are in a libvirt
group, we can drop the libvirt_ from in front of many of the flag
names. I haven't done this where it would leave us with what I felt
was an overly generic flag name (for example libvirt.type), but
perhaps that's me being overly conservative.

Progresses blueprint libvirt-opts-group.

DocImpact: the following flags have had the libvirt_ dropped from
the start of their flag name now that they are in a flag group:
    libvirt_inject_password
    libvirt_inject_key
    libvirt_inject_partition
    libvirt_vif_driver
    libvirt_volume_drivers
    libvirt_disk_prefix
    libvirt_wait_soft_reboot_seconds
    libvirt_non_blocking
    libvirt_cpu_mode
    libvirt_cpu_model
    libvirt_snapshots_directory

Change-Id: Ia3875e48dd75c26d05332f8356368ae38f264e4e

- gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron-large-ops http://logs.openstack.org/09/54509/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron-large-ops/e433275 : SUCCESS in 17m 30s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 6794, 'date': '2013-10-30 13:12:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The current change isn't enough for security groups to work. The rules generated by the OVSHybridIptablesFirewallDriver driver don't match with the VIF model used by the XenAPI driver. For instance, I've got rules like this on my dom0 server:

-A neutron-openvswi-FORWARD -m physdev  --physdev-out tapcff25d23-4f --physdev-is-bridged -j neutron-openvswi-sg-chain 
-A neutron-openvswi-FORWARD -m physdev  --physdev-in tapcff25d23-4f --physdev-is-bridged -j neutron-openvswi-sg-chain 

But there is no tapcff25d23-4f VIF, it's rather vifX.Y."}, {'account_id': 6794, 'date': '2013-10-31 08:21:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

need to add a dedicated driver for Dom0 iptables that would translate Neutron ports to Xen VIF names.'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-10-31 10:08:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Simon, Could you share your localrc with us?'}, {'account_id': 6794, 'date': '2013-10-31 10:19:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Hi Mate,

I've done all my tests without devstack so no localrc to share sorry.

I've installed my testbed with packstack + done manual modifications. My Neutron/Nova configuration is here:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/50274/

Tell me if you need more details."}, {'account_id': 6794, 'date': '2013-11-07 09:00:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Abandoning the patch until we get more information about this bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1248859

Unless I'm wrong, implementing security groups with iptables + XenAPI + OVS requires heavy changes in the XenAPI VIF driver since iptables doesn't work with OVS ports."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-30 09:46:06.000000000', 'message': 'Support security groups with XenAPI and OVS

iptables-restore and ip6tables-restore commands read their data from the
standard input. The neutron-rootwrap-xen-dom0 script and the netwrap
plugin have been modified to pass stdin from one to the other.
The netwrap plugin is also modified to allow iptables/ip6tables
commands.

Change-Id: I2b2d5589ffb14d11aef8f3d9c870fc5104433767
Closes-Bug: #1245809
'}]
commit_message:
Support security groups with XenAPI and OVS

iptables-restore and ip6tables-restore commands read their data from the
standard input. The neutron-rootwrap-xen-dom0 script and the netwrap
plugin have been modified to pass stdin from one to the other.
The netwrap plugin is also modified to allow iptables/ip6tables
commands.

Change-Id: I2b2d5589ffb14d11aef8f3d9c870fc5104433767
Closes-Bug: #1245809

[{'created': '2013-11-06 04:27:55.000000000', 'message': "Remove native_pxe option.

This removes the Nova 'native_pxe' config option and just
sets dhcp_options_enabled=true by default in our nova.conf
config file. This will ensure Neutron native PXE is always
our default now and allow us to remove this option from
the heat templates as well.

Change-Id: I50da826666a30e65167f888dba7f48dbbf5f0b2a
"}]
commit_message:
Remove native_pxe option.

This removes the Nova 'native_pxe' config option and just
sets dhcp_options_enabled=true by default in our nova.conf
config file. This will ensure Neutron native PXE is always
our default now and allow us to remove this option from
the heat templates as well.

Change-Id: I50da826666a30e65167f888dba7f48dbbf5f0b2a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-29 16:42:54.000000000', 'message': 'Preserve symlinks when writing output

Sometimes a config file will have to exist as a readonly symlink on the
root filesystem pointing to a writable storage area. We need to be able
to write to that config file in this case.

Fixes bug #1245953

Change-Id: I9af0f163c0a201222c0d09f7f2c5acc539088df6
'}]
commit_message:
Preserve symlinks when writing output

Sometimes a config file will have to exist as a readonly symlink on the
root filesystem pointing to a writable storage area. We need to be able
to write to that config file in this case.

Fixes bug #1245953

Change-Id: I9af0f163c0a201222c0d09f7f2c5acc539088df6

commit_message:
netapp: replaced e.message with unicode(e)

BaseException.message has been deprecated as of Python 2.6

Not fixed cinder/openstack/common/timeutils.py in favor
of pulling from Oslo.

Change-Id: I4cbcefa37a4a9fe07d27bd906d8b81f07704ac98

We should add a test for it."}, {'account_id': 6807, 'date': '2013-10-30 13:40:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

Actually, I was quite surprised to see the tests run successfully without having to adapt them after such a major change. Seems indeed more work is necessary. Thanks for all the comments on this.

Unfortunately I'm currently too busy with other things to look into this and haven't ever really written tests or any other serious Ruby code myself. So if someone would like to take over, please do. Otherwise, I might eventually get to it."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-07 06:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

commit_message:
Change default database connection to using mongodb

Upstream uses MongoDB by default and, worse, SQL Alchemy (and
thereby MySQL) support is not fully functional yet.

Change-Id: I50c6efd0b632035038065ca9e1fa09f3a8d781fd

- gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron-large-ops http://logs.openstack.org/46/54446/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron-large-ops/baa7769 : SUCCESS in 17m 49s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 7135, 'date': '2013-10-30 03:33:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The tenant ids are already ensured to be the same here,  https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L236. Can you please elaborate more on the problem you met? Or am i missing something here? Thanks."}, {'account_id': 9062, 'date': '2013-10-30 04:25:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If you ever try to parse.Stack.load a stack using an admin context (generated with context.py#get_admin_context), you run into unnecessary problems.  

An admin context is not associated to a specific tenant, but api.py#stack_get will still return the stack from the database with the 'admin' flag set to True.  So if I call #stack_get with an admin_context and admin=True, I will receive the stack back from the database.  But this new parse.Stack object will have problems calling #store and #identifier because the context does not have a tenant_id.

Since we pulled the stack out of the database, we have the real tenant_id already, and we should use that instead of depending on the context.tenant_id."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-10-30 08:04:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So, this, and related https://review.openstack.org/#/c/54395/ probably do make sense IMO, so thanks, however I'm still a little unsure about what actual issue they are solving.

Can you please expand on when you've actually observed these "unnecessary problems"?

In the current heat codebase, we should never be storing a stack with the admin_context, we should always be performing deferred operations with the stored context, retrieved by _load_user_creds - this will have the correct tenant ID.

So before we approve this, I'd really like to make sure we're not missing some other related issue, like inappropriate use of the admin_context somewhere.'}, {'account_id': 9062, 'date': '2013-10-30 15:12:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

For context, we started looking into this code while assessing changes needed for this blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/management-api

The scenario I described was a hypothetical, and you brought up valid points about not parsing a stack with an admin context.  In the current codebase, I don't believe anyone initializes a parser.Stack object with an admin context.  That specific scenario can be ignored since the behavior would be the same with or without this patch.

When parse.Stack.load'ing a stack, either from a given one or by fetching one from the database, we ensure that the tenant information comes from the object in the database.  If the stack being parsed was not from the database, we continue to use the tenant_id from the context, as it was before."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-07 06:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-07 06:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-29 23:18:35.000000000', 'message': 'parser.Stack accepts tenant_id as a param

Previously, parser.Stack was exclusively using the tenant_id from
the request context.  However, when we load an existing stack, it makes
sense to use the existing tenant information from the stack in the
db (the source of truth) rather than the tenant info from the request
context.

Change-Id: I0906cf067e7a3c3fb29a427b6fb7b49f2ee859a4
Closes-Bug: 1246123
'}]
commit_message:
parser.Stack accepts tenant_id as a param

Previously, parser.Stack was exclusively using the tenant_id from
the request context.  However, when we load an existing stack, it makes
sense to use the existing tenant information from the stack in the
db (the source of truth) rather than the tenant info from the request
context.

Change-Id: I0906cf067e7a3c3fb29a427b6fb7b49f2ee859a4
Closes-Bug: 1246123

Adding testcase for dhcp agent scheduler

Testcase for dhcp agent scheduler were missing.
At first stage api test to List DHCP agents hosting network is added.
part of blueprint: dhcp-agent-scheduler-api-testcases

commit_message:
Pluggable Extentions using multiple routes

Extentions can be organized in external directories
and linked to the trove code using configuration parameter
'api_extensions_dirlist', containing by default
'trove/extensions/routes' refering to default routes.

Change-Id: I321fa1c1afaa7d0ee3faf92e984520f887595f29
Implements: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/extension-pluggable

commit_message:
feat(mongo): starts to use aggregation for stats

Aggregation pipeline might be slower than normal queries,
but in this approach we can combine two queries into one.

Change-Id: I2fad0834b7ee72970405ae745b152a87fcddf2c3
Closes-Bug: 1218789

commit_message:
No session_persistence information added

Added information to session_persistence attribute for VIP in main table.
Update: Fixed tag movement and moved session_persistence info to footnote as there didn't seem to be a way to break it in the table. Works better for me there anyway.

Closes-Bug: #1231905

Change-Id: I30b454d7555f9385cd85a8ca4f02acb9f31d5e39

commit_message:
Raised an exception if no DHCP agent is active or alive

When a port is created, the plugin sends a RPC cast to the DHCP
agent(s) which assume this network in order to update their host file.
If the agent(s) aren't available (admin state down or not alive),
the patch delete the created port and raised an exception.

The patch modify DHCP notification. If the subnet has DHCP disable or if
a port doesn't have fixed IPs, no notifications or scheduling are set.

The patch adds a mock on method '_get_dhcp_agents' of the
'DhcpAgentNotifyAPI' class in the 'NeutronDbPluginV2TestCase' test
class in order to keep plugins run tests valid for plugins which
support 'dhcp_agent_scheduler' extension.

Link to bug #1185916

Change-Id: I0990c5a36dff6d716494a8bf479bf20d32bb6ec2

commit_message:
Add an install-packages element

With this element we can reduce image size and build time by making
package installation declarative and taking steps to reduce repeated
work. Many elements will need to be updated to use it, and we will
also need to add remove-packages scripts to the distro elements.

Change-Id: I8ee4708fb703ad12fcf9baa0aca76bcbbb760801
