'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-10-29 02:52:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not real keen on releasing internal config/node info to end-users.  If I read the BP correctly the intent is more for Nova and other services, in which case we should make it explicit to those services not open it up to "any user" as you have in the commit message.'}, {'account_id': 681, 'date': '2013-10-29 03:09:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

John, while I see the reasoning behind your comments, I am wondering what are the alternatives to get cross services visibility. One option is to have a scheduler context (like admin) but that needs more discussion.'}, {'account_id': 8514, 'date': '2013-10-29 03:12:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi John, 

In order to achieve cross services scheduling, i.e., say Nova scheduling decision based on the Cinder data, such as volume host info, we need the right context that has visibility to this data.  But from Nova, when we are making a Cinder client api call, using a context of any user, there is no way to elevate the context for Cinder.  Within nova, for scheduling purposes, we can elevate the context, but that is lost when making the call to cinder.  Hence we may need special privileges to get this cinder info with admin privileges, just for scheduling.  Any thoughts? 
Hence this commit, was to allow that host info be visible.  Any other way possible to allow this information visible to Nova for any user for the purpose of scheduling ?
Thanks,
Yathi.'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-10-29 05:52:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with John - this information should not be exposed to users.  Maybe policy can help here?  I seem to recall that some deployments give access only to Nova to call attach/detach using policy."}, {'account_id': 681, 'date': '2013-10-29 05:58:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

It would be good to visit a more basic question: given the need to schedule a VM based on the location of the volumes, what are the options? I think the current code base is one of the ways but there is a question about contexts ... As I pointed earlier, we should have scheduler contexts! I think we could keep this as an option.'}, {'account_id': 8514, 'date': '2013-10-29 06:05:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I agree with Debo, as a scheduler context, might give the cross service schedulers a special privilege to access this information.  Here, we have to be careful and ensure that no non-admin user will not be able to take on a scheduler context.
 
But, what are the options available in the current code base to enable this, as we are calling cinder api from within nova using the cinder client?  Elevating the context within nova doesn't help, as it is not transferred to cinder api."}, {'account_id': 8890, 'date': '2013-10-29 07:58:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I agree that it would be good to have this as an option for enabling cross-service scheduling.'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2013-10-30 23:04:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-07 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-07 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

commit_message:
Relax volume_host_attribute policies

The current policies for cinder allow only admin users to retrieve
the hostname where a volume is placed. In order to perform
cross-service scheduling we need this information to be available
for any user, as the is_admin flag of an elevated context is not
sent to cinder when using the REST api.
Tests have also been modified to adapt to this new behavior.

blueprint cross-service-filter-scheduling

Change-Id: I3a755dfb9bae66183d11d81afe9b5d266c7a7d15

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-30 15:09:24.000000000', 'message': 'Fix the image name of a shelved server

The shelve feature powers a server off, and creates a snapshot of the
server. The snapshot image name is "instance-XXXXXXXXX-shelved" and it
doesn't contain a server name like the following:

  $ nova list
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  | ID | Name | Status | Task State | Power State | Networks         |
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  | .. | vm01 | ACTIVE | None       | Running     | private=10.0.0.5 |
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  $ nova shelve vm01
  $ nova image-list
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  | ID | Name                            | Status | Server |
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  | .. | instance-00000004-shelved       | ACTIVE | ..     |
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  $

"instance-XXXXXXXXX" is OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:instance_name, and a non-admin
cannot see it.

This patch changes the name to "<server name>-shelved", so that a non-
admin user can know the server name of a shelved image:

  $ nova image-list
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  | ID | Name               | Status | Server |
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  | .. | vm01-shelved       | ACTIVE | ..     |
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  $

Closes-Bug: 1232991

Change-Id: Idc73658e29cb77dfcc8b046535a36affc1831605
(cherry picked from commit abec25a7bafa4ca320ae222a34fc45ad3c1d27a8)
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix the image name of a shelved server

The shelve feature powers a server off, and creates a snapshot of the
server. The snapshot image name is "instance-XXXXXXXXX-shelved" and it
doesn't contain a server name like the following:

  $ nova list
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  | ID | Name | Status | Task State | Power State | Networks         |
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  | .. | vm01 | ACTIVE | None       | Running     | private=10.0.0.5 |
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  $ nova shelve vm01
  $ nova image-list
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  | ID | Name                            | Status | Server |
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  | .. | instance-00000004-shelved       | ACTIVE | ..     |
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  $

"instance-XXXXXXXXX" is OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:instance_name, and a non-admin
cannot see it.

This patch changes the name to "<server name>-shelved", so that a non-
admin user can know the server name of a shelved image:

  $ nova image-list
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  | ID | Name               | Status | Server |
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  | .. | vm01-shelved       | ACTIVE | ..     |
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  $

Closes-Bug: 1232991

Change-Id: Idc73658e29cb77dfcc8b046535a36affc1831605
(cherry picked from commit abec25a7bafa4ca320ae222a34fc45ad3c1d27a8)
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Sync units module from olso

There are lots of numeric expressions across some projects, such as
1024*1024 , 1024**3, 1000, 1000000 etc. This patch adds binary and
decimal unit constants. Replacing nummeric experssions with these
constants makes code more readable.

Change-Id: I45fb5a10009f22b1eedb07b3e52f1ce40403b068

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-06 07:17:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fix import log_handler error with publish_errors set

Sync from Olso.
Commit Id is Ibf28ba17f81b5ddeda653f6a3501ecac18ffcd42

This handler sends all error logs as rpc notifications.
Note: when using publish_errors you also need to set the
notification_driver option too.

Closes-bug: #1240349
Change-Id: I0d3ded8bdb5a26d67672d482979eea131e0ade3f
'}]
commit_message:
Fix import log_handler error with publish_errors set

Sync from Olso.
Commit Id is Ibf28ba17f81b5ddeda653f6a3501ecac18ffcd42

This handler sends all error logs as rpc notifications.
Note: when using publish_errors you also need to set the
notification_driver option too.

Closes-bug: #1240349
Change-Id: I0d3ded8bdb5a26d67672d482979eea131e0ade3f

"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-23 14:23:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

I like the general direction of this - a few minor points / questions in the comments.

The main change I'd like to see is some way for a compute manager to override the clean-up period (which is just an optimization) if the system is under space pressure - otherwise we could end up being out of space in the period when there are lots of shelved instances still on hosts

Maybe a host should be able to reject a first attempt at placement of a new VM if is doesn't have space due to shelved hosts, but has to accept (and immediately delete shelved storage) for an nth attempt"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-06-24 18:26:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Maybe a better idea is to add an admin operation to force the saving of a shelved instance?

It could take a long time to shelve some instances, so I don't fancy it happening during scheduling. But if you spot a big capacity issue, its good to have the option of freeing up some capacity easily. And clearly that could be triggered by something outside nova, in the case you need something more complex that then default nova behavior."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2013-06-24 19:34:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

What is your plan for allocated networking components related to shelved instances? These are billable implications for service providers."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-24 20:15:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

Phil,

I was pretty sure that, deservedly so, the clean-up was going to be the tricky part to get right for various use cases.  I'd like to make this as useful as possible without getting overly complicated.  

I like John's idea of admin functionality for forced cleanup and think it's a good direction, at least to start with.  

I think a dynamic clean-up period could be useful as well, but I don't know what to trigger it off of.  There's not really a component in Nova that understands capacity across the system except the scheduler, and I don't know if it's right for the scheduler to poke a compute node for cleanup.

Are you amenable to an admin button for now and fleshing something better out later?"}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-24 20:21:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Trey, the plan is to have notifications for shelving events which allow a service provider to bill for this appropriately.  Retaining networking components is one of the key features for shelving, but service providers should have the information they need to bill for those resources.  If those notifications are missing, and I see some are right now, that needs to be fixed.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-24 21:22:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

After asking Steven Hardy on IRC, we agree there first needs to be a nova vs heat discussion on the ML.  In other words a clear argument why this belongs in nova and not heat (as this sounds very much like orchestration)'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-25 01:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Hi Joe,

It may sound like orchestration, but I don't really think that it is.  These are atomic operations that a compute manager needs to perform. 

Before this gets derailed into an ML discussion on Nova vs Heat can you be more explicit about which parts of the operation you'd want Heat to do ?

I'm also very wary of having what should be core Nova capability depending on having Heat also deployed - being able to really "stop" an instance (rather than just power it off) is seen as a big feature gap by many of our customers.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-25 17:54:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-28 21:44:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I see you have removed the periodic task. That still leaves the question of how unshelving works when the node the instance was shelved on gets another instance scheduled to it.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-29 00:45:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't understand why the periodic task was taken away (Sorry Joe I just think you were wrong here)

The intended flow here is:
1) Shelve the instance, leaving the files in place for some configurable period
2) Delete files that associated with the instance

During the time between 1) and 2) the instance still counts against the consumed capacity of the host.
If an unshelve happens before 2) then the instance can be quickly restored on the same host
If an unshelve happens after 2) then the instance has to be rescheduled.

2) can only be achieved with a periodic task - and the previous patch set did that.

As a cloud provider I can decide what the interval is between 1) and 2) - depending on how long I'm willing to allow that (now unpaid for) capacity to be consumed.

So can we go back to the previous patch set please ?


A nice enhancement would be to allow the user to specify the gap between 1) and 2) - and track this as a specific state.  That way the cloud provider could charge diffrently for this period, and the user has the choice over cost vs recovery speed."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-29 11:16:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Joe, Phil's explanation is exactly what I'm thinking.  An instance won't get scheduled to a full host with shelved instances there as they'll count against capacity until they're offloaded.

Phil, I mean to have the periodic task in another commit just to minimize the controversy to a small portion of code and not hold up the rest.  I'd like to get the periodic task and the admin API method for cleanup both in Nova, and then leave it open for other external mechanisms(Heat) to trigger the cleanup if they'd like.

I agree that using this feature shouldn't rely on deploying another service so there should be a cleanup built into Nova.  I also agree that a deployer wishing to use an external trigger should be able to do so, in which case they can disable the periodic task and do that."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-30 06:47:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Andrew, Phil. The part I am unclear on is the gap between  step 1 and 2 of the intended workflow as Phil defined it.

While the instance is shelved on the compute node and still counts as a consumed resource, I don't see much value to the deployer.  It sounds like  there  would only be negligible power savings.  So why not just make shelving the instance do both steps 1 and 2 at the same time?  If I as an instance owner am concerned about how long it takes to unshelve the instance, I can just put the unshelving on a timer.  

Also as a instance owner I would be confused if sometimes unshelving takes a few seconds and sometimes it takes minutes.  I would want the same action to take the take roughly the same order of magnitude of time no matter when I do it.

I guess what I am getting that, is that I see shelving as snapshotting the instance and moving it to cold storage, and  if I want to keep an instance on a compute node in a non-running state I can just pause it."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-07-01 14:22:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Joe,

To resolve the confusion between unshelving times I can add another state to make it explicit what the shelved state is.

From a deployer standpoint the value is the flexibility to leave it or remove it, and the space savings if removed.  I'm coding this for a deployer who would like to leave instances remaining on the hypervisor for a period of time, and remove them at will.  That may not make the most sense for all deployers, but I don't see a reason to not be flexible about this.

I see three possibilities for how an instance is removed from the hypervisor:

1) Removal immediately upon shelving.
2) Removal at some period after shelving.
3) Removal at will based on API call.

I have use cases for 2 & 3, but not 1.  Now, I don't want to make it hard to implement 1, but I don't see why code for cases 2 & 3 should be held up since those are also valid use cases without 1."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-07-01 21:27:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-01 22:11:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

(1 inline comment)

So I get that we now have the action in api to offload a shelved instance, but there is nothing in the patch that I can see that actually drives it, so its not clear to me that as it stands this fully implements any of the 3 use cases that you set out in your last message.

I still can't see what's wrong with including the periodic task and using the value of the associated config flag as:

-1 no automatic offload
0  offload immediately after shelve
n  offload after n minutes

Seems that would allow this change to fully implement all 3 cases and allow the cloud provided to configure to whichever case they want to implement.

Also an in-line comment on offloading"}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-07-02 13:30:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

There's a separate API patchset for drivers(WIP), and I'll push up the periodic task as soon as I get this finished with tests working so I'm not rebasing constantly.

I've considered splitting this into two patches to keep the size down but RPC versioning makes me want to do this all at once."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-07-02 18:22:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-07-02 18:50:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-02 19:52:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

"The reason why is that right now there is a time cost associated with rescheduling an instance and rebuilding it from a snapshot. So a deployer might decide to accept the cost of retaining the instance for a time in order to smooth out the user experience." 

This seems like a strange solution to me, treating the symptoms not the cause.  If scheduling /rebuilding is slow make that faster.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-07-04 10:50:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

A few nits in the code, but I like the approach.

Joe makes an interesting point about the default. For volume backed instances, making them disappear by default makes sense.  However, I feel that work should be in a follow up change that looks at "scheduling" the offload, whether that be immediate or not.

Fundamentally, the VM disks could by TBs in size, so it will never be "quick" to create the image, and bring it back to the hypervisor. I like that optimization.

Indeed, saving some of that network load would lead me to say we might want (in the future) to look at taking the image during the offload process. But clearly this is different to the current approach which is more like a soft_delete with backup.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-04 11:22:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: No score

The time factor comes from fetching the image from Glance - whilst we'd all like that to be faster is that really something to hang on this change ?

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-21 19:09:13.000000000', 'message': 'Shelve/unshelve an instance

The basic idea is that an instance can be put into a shelved state which
snapshots it, unless volume backed, and powers it down.  A periodic task
on the compute nodes will clean up the instance after a configurable
period of time(default: 3 days).  This should allow for fast startup
times when an instance is shelved for a night or over a weekend, and
free up resources when left longer.

bp shelve-instance

Change-Id: I908474915c5325e120a64af9b9af13fcbce1f01c
'}, {'created': '2013-06-27 21:33:53.000000000', 'message': 'Shelve/unshelve an instance

This adds the compute methods for shelving and unshelving.  Shelving
will power down the instance, and snapshot if not volume backed.
Unshelving will restore the instance, which may involve re-scheduling
and rebuilding it from a snapshot.

Part of bp shelve-instance

Change-Id: I908474915c5325e120a64af9b9af13fcbce1f01c

commit_message:
Shelve/unshelve an instance

This adds the compute methods for shelving and unshelving.  Shelving
will power down the instance, and snapshot if not volume backed.
Unshelving will restore the instance, which may involve re-scheduling
and rebuilding it from a snapshot.

Part of bp shelve-instance

Co-Author: Dan Smith <danms@us.ibm.com> (Instance objects)
Change-Id: I908474915c5325e120a64af9b9af13fcbce1f01c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-23 06:47:23.000000000', 'message': 'Modification for Ubuntu 13.10 and minor fixes in Neutron NEC plugin

Modifications for Ubuntu 13.10:
* Add .conf suffix to apache2 config files. In Ubuntu 13.10,
  files in sites-available should have ".conf" suffix.
  Otherwise it is not recognized by a2ensite.
* libglib2.0-dev is added to lib/files/apt/trema. Trema is
  an OpenFlow controler framework used by Neutron NEC plugin
  Ubuntu package dependency seems to be changed.

Minor cleanups are also done in OVS configuration:
* Set datapath_id before connecting to the OpenFlow controller
  to ensure datapath_id changes after connected.
  Previously datapath_id is changed after connecting to the controller.
* Drop "0x" prefix from datapath_id passed to OVS.
  OVS ignores datapath_id with 0x prefix.
* Fix a bug that SKIP_OVS_BRIDGE_SETUP skips all confiugration of
  the plugin agent. It should skip only OVS setup.

Change-Id: Ifac3def8decda577b5740c82fe8d24e8520c7777
'}]
commit_message:
Modification for Ubuntu 13.10 and minor fixes in Neutron NEC plugin

Modifications for Ubuntu 13.10:
* Add .conf suffix to apache2 config files. In Ubuntu 13.10,
  files in sites-available should have ".conf" suffix.
  Otherwise it is not recognized by a2ensite.
* libglib2.0-dev is added to lib/files/apt/trema. Trema is
  an OpenFlow controler framework used by Neutron NEC plugin
  Ubuntu package dependency seems to be changed.

Minor cleanups are also done in OVS configuration:
* Set datapath_id before connecting to the OpenFlow controller
  to ensure datapath_id changes after connected.
  Previously datapath_id is changed after connecting to the controller.
* Drop "0x" prefix from datapath_id passed to OVS.
  OVS ignores datapath_id with 0x prefix.
* Fix a bug that SKIP_OVS_BRIDGE_SETUP skips all confiugration of
  the plugin agent. It should skip only OVS setup.

Change-Id: Ifac3def8decda577b5740c82fe8d24e8520c7777

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-29 21:41:14.000000000', 'message': "Clear correct device when deleting a ThinLVM snap

The LVM driver tries to wipe a device using dd when
a snapshot is deleted.  For ThinLVM, it is attempting
to wipe the /dev/mapper/cinder--volumes-<vol>-cow device,
which does not exist for ThinLVM.  This causes snapshot
deletion to fail for ThinLVM if volume clearing is on.

When using ThinLVM, only wipe the LV device rather than
attempting to wipe the -cow device.

This bug is only present in stable/grizzly (2013.1.4).
It does not exist in stable/havana or master due to these
changes:
f702fe7 Fix secure delete for thick LVM snapshots
de43923 Don't zero out thin provisioned LV's on delete

Closes-Bug: #1245529
Change-Id: I1d8dd618e51cc99b8947fbe0697a1c765c8251ba
"}]
commit_message:
Clear correct device when deleting a ThinLVM snap

The LVM driver tries to wipe a device using dd when
a snapshot is deleted.  For ThinLVM, it is attempting
to wipe the /dev/mapper/cinder--volumes-<vol>-cow device,
which does not exist for ThinLVM.  This causes snapshot
deletion to fail for ThinLVM if volume clearing is on.

When using ThinLVM, only wipe the LV device rather than
attempting to wipe the -cow device.

This bug is only present in stable/grizzly (2013.1.4).
It does not exist in stable/havana or master due to these
changes:
f702fe7 Fix secure delete for thick LVM snapshots
de43923 Don't zero out thin provisioned LV's on delete

Closes-Bug: #1245529
Change-Id: I1d8dd618e51cc99b8947fbe0697a1c765c8251ba

commit_message:
Use heat's default value for max_template_size

Instead of aligning value with tempest, make tempest use heat's default
value as that is what most people will be deploying with.

Change-Id: I77549f2b5e953ff712c50a2b372f6b04725d5eb0

commit_message:
removed unecessary lines for docker install

* script was trying to copy file from a source
	that doesn't exist to destination that does.
* variable DOCKER_BRANCH no longer used.

Change-Id: I50fd55e97dfc4eaaa3c1f2bfc42e8cfc0e76cdf4

[{'created': '2013-10-28 09:51:36.000000000', 'message': 'Cleanup unused settings, use interface_driver setter

* Remove unused MIDONET specific settings from nova.conf
* Remove unused MIDONET specific settings from dhcp_agent.ini
* Move the interface_driver settings to the proper setting
  function so that it can be used by lbaas_agent.ini as well.

Change-Id: Id686ff5f55db00bce42b8a2bd56e7655c73211fb
Closes-Bug: #1245401
'}]
commit_message:
Cleanup unused settings, use interface_driver setter

* Remove unused MIDONET specific settings from nova.conf
* Remove unused MIDONET specific settings from dhcp_agent.ini
* Move the interface_driver settings to the proper setting
  function so that it can be used by lbaas_agent.ini as well.

Change-Id: Id686ff5f55db00bce42b8a2bd56e7655c73211fb
Closes-Bug: #1245401

commit_message:
Refactors byte size extraction logic

The logic of _extract_bytes() in imageutils.QemuImgInfo
is not efficient. See
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/41363/11/openstack/common/imageutils.py

This patch enhances the regex pattern to extract the byte size info
more efficiently.

Change-Id: I6efb3a6020179ac93c9d7848403c0fad0ebb1d1c

commit_message:
Fixed non-zero default policy index

Fixes integer conditional in the proxy container controller.
_backend_requests adds the policy header if the policy_index provided
evaluates to true. If policy with index 0 is not the default it can
never be set as it evalutes to false. Switched this statement to check
if policy_index is not None.

Closes-Bug: #1246107
Change-Id: I34a0551af1f07db76bb16844f6d11b515737a38f

commit_message:
Check return code of command instead of checking stderr

Command "ip link show" return a no 0 return code when passing
a no existing ip interface so we should use the return code
instead of checking stderr because stderr can contain messages
from the system even though the command succeeded.

Change-Id: Ic43e72dab3c5b6e266240b7ff7309ca3b44f8ed5
Closes-Bug: #1248699

commit_message:
Fix the boto version comparison

Use versionutils to check the boto version in parsed form rather than
comparing text.

Fixes bug: 1239890

Change-Id: Iea421ab0d86ce29648a8b8f757456364ea21e956

subject: Alternate DiskFile constructor for efficient auditing.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-29 01:30:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-swift-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/17/54217/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/1365f75 : SUCCESS in 1m 13s
- gate-swift-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/17/54217/1/check/gate-swift-docs/b581d89/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 00s

- check-tempest-devstack-vm-full http://logs.openstack.org/17/54217/1/check/check-tempest-devstack-vm-full/b8b2209 : SUCCESS in 30m 19s
- check-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron http://logs.openstack.org/17/54217/1/check/check-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron/f17adbf : SUCCESS in 19m 01s
- check-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full http://logs.openstack.org/17/54217/1/check/check-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/473c523 : SUCCESS in 30m 47s
- gate-tempest-devstack-vm-large-ops http://logs.openstack.org/17/54217/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-large-ops/f1ad148 : SUCCESS in 14m 12s
- gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron-large-ops http://logs.openstack.org/17/54217/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron-large-ops/1f9a30f : SUCCESS in 17m 15s (non-voting)
- check-grenade-devstack-vm http://logs.openstack.org/17/54217/1/check/check-grenade-devstack-vm/cce7fdf : SUCCESS in 24m 51s
'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-10-29 02:54:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

In general, I am not in-favor of implementation details bleeding out through the defined API. This is the main reason for the approach taken with https://review.openstack.org/44787. I hope we do not take this approach as it sets a precedent I feel we should avoid.

I think the optimization improvements can be made to the alternative approach just as well as they were made here, so that is probably not the deciding factor here."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-10-29 03:52:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

There's a couple of things I like better here, code-wise, than in https://review.openstack.org/44787

The main one is that this doesn't duplicate the reader logic. The other one has two loops that read a chunk off the disk, update a checksum, advise the kernel to drop the cache, and then finally compare computed-checksum and metadata-checksum.

Also, here, there's only one class that ever quarantines, so swift.obj.diskfile.DiskFile gains a new constructor in its API, but swift.obj.diskfile loses quarantine_renamer as part of its API, so maybe it's a wash? Either way, there's one auditor-specific thing kind of sticking out the side.

Seems a little cleaner to me to have all the quarantining happening in the confines of a single module, but that's just like, my opinion, man.

I'd also thought about having the auditor treat an audit location as an opaque thing, so rather than unpacking into (path, device, partition), just leave it as an opaque thingy and leave the tuple-unpacking to DiskFile. It made the logging a little uglier, though, so I opted not to. It's not hard to bring back if it'd help, though.

I dunno; it's sort of hard to figure out what the right thing to do here is. We've got the good old filesystem DiskFile that needs to support replication and auditing and blah blah blah, the Gluster one that avoids some of that stuff by delegating that to the underlying storage (I think), and then someday Clay's wacky key/value Kinetic DiskFile that will need to do all the replication and auditing too, but its auditing might end up looking completely unlike filesystem auditing."}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-10-29 14:31:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-10-29 22:52:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I stopped all SAIO swift services.  I then edited a file by hand and changed its count of bytes.  So I guess the auditor's Content-Length sanity-check manifests as a "reading metadata" error.

I started just the object-auditor and the logging seems funny:

  ...ERROR Object /srv/node/d3/objects/72/481/1221cfb95ddd98287352e198af934481 failed audit and was quarantined: Exception reading metadata: 
  ...Object audit (ZBF) "forever" mode completed: 168.86s. Total quarantined: 0, Total errors: 0, Total files/sec: 50.01 , Total bytes/sec: 0.00, Auditing time: 168.38, Rate: 1.00
  ...Object audit (ZBF) "forever" mode completed: 168.88s. Total quarantined: 0, Total errors: 0, Total files/sec: 50.01 , Total bytes/sec: 0.00, Auditing time: 168.32, Rate: 1.00
  ...Object audit (ZBF) "forever" mode completed: 168.90s. Total quarantined: 0, Total errors: 0, Total files/sec: 50.01 , Total bytes/sec: 0.00, Auditing time: 168.32, Rate: 1.00
  ...Object audit (ZBF) "forever" mode completed: 168.88s. Total quarantined: 0, Total errors: 0, Total files/sec: 50.01 , Total bytes/sec: 0.00, Auditing time: 168.34, Rate: 1.00

For one, the exception reading the metadata seems... truncated?  And then one of the four object-auditors' log lines should indicate that a file was quarantined (they all say 0).'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-10-30 19:54:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Darrell: https://review.openstack.org/54620 fixes the count discrepancy.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-10-30 20:14:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I can reproduce the empty log message sometimes... it seems that if the concatenation of user.swift.metadata* is not a valid pickle, then pickle raises an EOFError with an empty message (e.g. "EOFError()"), and so str(that error) is the empty string, and that's what you see in the logs.

For other things, such as changing the etag in the metadata or editing the content length, a proper log message is produced.

This happens on master (fab1cd4) as well, so at least this patch doesn't make the log messages worse.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-10-31 02:30:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Ran into this same issue with https://review.openstack.org/44787. Addressed it there as well (see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/44787/16/swift/obj/diskfile.py, line 380).'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-10-31 18:36:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(2 inline comments)

This no longer appears to bleed implementation details out through the API, causing another implementation to have to also accept the quarantine_hook parameter.

Besides the doc stuff mentioned in line, and what appears to be an unnecessary change, this looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-10-31 19:17:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Really personal opinions here but:

I'd prefer to see object_audit_location_generator be part of DiskFileManager.

It seems more logical for get_diskfile_from_audit_location and from_hash_dir to have the hash_dir_path as an argument after device and partition, in my opinion. Then again, I wouldn't have it as a complete override path but rather as an obj_hash only and let the implementation decide on the underlying structure.

Not sure it matters, but DiskFileReader would now require a quarantine_hook? Seems it could be optional."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-11-04 23:42:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Seems we've reached a bit of an impasse here.

As far as I can tell, Peter wants DiskFile (both the class and the module) to be a thing for only the object server, and anything else (like the auditor) is purely optional stuff.

In opposition to that, Greg would like to have object_audit_location_generator  moved into diskfile (the module), which adds stuff to diskfile that doesn't get used by the object server at all.

So, if those are both correct paraphrasings, then there needs to be some discussion to figure out what's the right thing to do. Personally, I prefer Greg's approach, as it means both the construction and consumption of audit locations happen in the same module, but it's not a terribly strong preference.

(If I'm wrong about what people think and you guys are actually in agreement, please tell me and I'll go make the appropriate changes. Thanks!)"}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-11-05 02:44:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: No score

@Sam, I support Greg's approach. Take a look at the latest patch set of https://review.openstack.org/44787 (Ween auditor off of DiskFile ...). Hopefully that supports the position that I still hold that the DiskFile class should be used by the object server REST API layer, and that the diskfile module can hold REST API and non-REST API support code.

I am sorry if in some way I communicated that the diskfile module should only be used by the Object Server's REST API layer (please point out reviews or statements that are prominent so that I can correct them or clarify, thanks)."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-11-05 21:04:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Peter: I guess I was confused about your thoughts on DiskFile-the-class versus diskfile-the-module, then.

Since it seems like we're all in agreement, I'll go scoot that code over to diskfile-the-module."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-11-05 21:05:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-11-05 21:18:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Sam: most likely I am the cause of the confusion, so I'll work to make sure I be clearer in the future about diskfile the module vs DiskFile the class.

And I remain in favor of this commit."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-11-06 00:06:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-11-06 00:53:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-29 01:00:01.000000000', 'message': 'Alternate DiskFile constructor for efficient auditing.

Before, to audit an object, the auditor:
 - calls listdir(object-hash-dir)
 - picks out the .data file from the listing
 - pulls out all N of its user.swift.metadata* xattrs
 - unpickles them
 - pulls out the value for 'name'
 - splits the name into a/c/o
 - then instantiates and opens a DiskFile(a, c, o),
which does the following
 - joins a/c/o back into a name
 - hashes the name
 - calls listdir(object-hash-dir) (AGAIN)
 - picks out the .data file (and maybe .meta) from the listing (AGAIN)
 - pulls out all N of its user.swift.metadata* xattrs (AGAIN)
 - unpickles them (AGAIN)
 - starts reading object's contents off disk

Now, the auditor simply locates the hash dir on the filesystem (saving
one listdir) and then hands it off to
DiskFileManager.get_diskfile_from_audit_location, which then
instantiates a DiskFile using the new .from_hash_dir() constructor,
which avoids the requirement to have a name (saving one xattr
reading).

As part of this, DiskFile.open() will now quarantine a hash
"directory" that's actually a file. Before, the audit location
generator would skip those, but now they make it clear into
DiskFile(). It's better to quarantine them anyway, as they're not
doing any good the way they are.

Also, removed the was_quarantined attribute on DiskFileReader. Now you
can pass in a quarantine_hook callable to DiskFile.reader() that gets
called if the file was quarantined. Default is to log quarantines, but
otherwise do nothing.

Change-Id: I04fc14569982a17fcc89e00832725ae71009335a

which does the following
 - joins a/c/o back into a name
 - hashes the name
 - calls listdir(object-hash-dir) (AGAIN)
 - picks out the .data file (and maybe .meta) from the listing (AGAIN)
 - pulls out all N of its user.swift.metadata* xattrs (AGAIN)
 - unpickles them (AGAIN)
 - starts reading object's contents off disk

Now, the auditor simply locates the hash dir on the filesystem (saving
one listdir) and then hands it off to
DiskFileManager.get_diskfile_from_audit_location, which then
instantiates a DiskFile using the new .from_hash_dir() constructor,
which avoids the requirement to have a name (saving one xattr
reading).

As part of this, DiskFile.open() will now quarantine a hash
"directory" that's actually a file. Before, the audit location
generator would skip those, but now they make it clear into
DiskFile(). It's better to quarantine them anyway, as they're not
doing any good the way they are.

Also, removed the was_quarantined attribute on DiskFileReader. Now you
can pass in a quarantine_hook callable to DiskFile.reader() that gets
called if the file was quarantined. Default is to log quarantines, but
otherwise do nothing.

Change-Id: I04fc14569982a17fcc89e00832725ae71009335a

commit_message:
Alternate DiskFile constructor for efficient auditing.

Before, to audit an object, the auditor:
 - calls listdir(object-hash-dir)
 - picks out the .data file from the listing
 - pulls out all N of its user.swift.metadata* xattrs
 - unpickles them
 - pulls out the value for 'name'
 - splits the name into a/c/o
 - then instantiates and opens a DiskFile(a, c, o),
which does the following
 - joins a/c/o back into a name
 - hashes the name
 - calls listdir(object-hash-dir) (AGAIN)
 - picks out the .data file (and maybe .meta) from the listing (AGAIN)
 - pulls out all N of its user.swift.metadata* xattrs (AGAIN)
 - unpickles them (AGAIN)
 - starts reading object's contents off disk

Now, the auditor simply locates the hash dir on the filesystem (saving
one listdir) and then hands it off to
DiskFileManager.get_diskfile_from_audit_location, which then
instantiates a DiskFile in a way that lazy-loads the name later
(saving one xattr reading).

As part of this, DiskFile.open() will now quarantine a hash
"directory" that's actually a file. Before, the audit location
generator would skip those, but now they make it clear into
DiskFile(). It's better to quarantine them anyway, as they're not
doing any good the way they are.

Also, removed the was_quarantined attribute on DiskFileReader. Now you
can pass in a quarantine_hook callable to DiskFile.reader() that gets
called if the file was quarantined. Default is to log quarantines, but
otherwise do nothing.

Change-Id: I04fc14569982a17fcc89e00832725ae71009335a

commit_message:
Fix swauth package install

Forgot to iterate over the attribute so swauth wasn't being installed.

* Add back in forgotten .each to the end of platform_options
* Fix specs to take account of the above
* Bump metadata

Change-Id: I235a1337fc60bcfbd0aa2c4f047e5a184d217027

[{'created': '2013-10-31 09:42:17.000000000', 'message': "Don't reset tasks to PENDING state while reverting

While flow is in REVERTING or REVERTED state, reverted tasks are now
left in REVERTED state. They are then reset to PENDING state when flow
is run again. With this change:

- when task is in REVERTED state, its result (if task were
  successfully executed before) is removed, but its failure (if its
  execution or reversion failed) is still available from storage;
- when flow is in REVERTED or FAILURE states, you can get all task
  failures from storage;
- if flow is in REVERTED or REVERTING state, but task is in PENDING
  state, it means this task was never executed;
- flow cannot transition from REVERTED to RUNNING state any more -- it
  should go through PENDING state; on REVERTED -> PENDING transition
  tasks of the flow are reset.

This ensures that failure is available until it becomes irrelevant.

Closes-bug: #1246612
Change-Id: I27c3891f5d412d6de6240638b5014afda94a58a4

commit_message:
Don't reset tasks to PENDING state while reverting

While flow is in REVERTING or REVERTED state, reverted tasks are now
left in REVERTED state. They are then reset to PENDING state when flow
is run again. With this change:

- when task is in REVERTED state, its result (if task were
  successfully executed before) is removed, but its failure (if its
  execution or reversion failed) is still available from storage;
- when flow is in REVERTED or FAILURE states, you can get all task
  failures from storage;
- if flow is in REVERTED or REVERTING state, but task is in PENDING
  state, it means this task was never executed;
- flow cannot transition from REVERTED to RUNNING state any more -- it
  should go through PENDING state; on REVERTED -> PENDING transition
  tasks of the flow are reset.

This ensures that failure information is available until it becomes
irrelevant.

Closes-bug: #1246612
Change-Id: I27c3891f5d412d6de6240638b5014afda94a58a4

commit_message:
Forced isolation for the nova quota test

Several test cases like quota related tests should not be done without
creating a new tenant in all cases.

This change enforces the isolated code path for the nova quota tests.
These tests requires admin rights anyway, so probably no one want to
try to run them without admin permissions.

Change-Id: Ib7550bc68f493ce9c6acbd57fc2d901e14ec2fef

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-23 16:55:00.000000000', 'message': "Fixes Hyper-V snapshot spawning issue

In Hyper-V, snapshoting an instance and then spawning a new
one using the resulted snapshot image with the same flavor,
will result an Hyper-V Exception.

Hyper-V will get the request to resize the base image to it's
actual size, leading to an error.

The reason is that the logic of the resize_vhd method has been
changed, as it is meant to resize images to the flavor size minus
the image metadata size, thus it's maximum internal size. For this
reason, the way to decide whether the root image should be resized
or not must also be changed.

So, instead of comparing the root image and base image sizes,
we should compare their maximum internal sizes.

Closes-Bug: #1234759

Change-Id: I83d2df76b726d705cedc52a8309a2be7037d6a79
(cherry picked from commit efdca8eeaffe6e63d57243147658f4691da3d89e)

commit_message:
Fixes Hyper-V snapshot spawning issue

In Hyper-V, snapshoting an instance and then spawning a new
one using the resulted snapshot image with the same flavor,
will result an Hyper-V Exception.

Hyper-V will get the request to resize the base image to it's
actual size, leading to an error.

The reason is that the logic of the resize_vhd method has been
changed, as it is meant to resize images to the flavor size minus
the image metadata size, thus it's maximum internal size. For this
reason, the way to decide whether the root image should be resized
or not must also be changed.

So, instead of comparing the root image and base image sizes,
we should compare their maximum internal sizes.

Closes-Bug: #1234759

Change-Id: I83d2df76b726d705cedc52a8309a2be7037d6a79
(cherry picked from commit efdca8eeaffe6e63d57243147658f4691da3d89e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-06 11:47:54.000000000', 'message': 'Use auth_url as mgmt_url if not admin identity

When admin identity endpoint is not found from the returned service catalog,
the given message error is ‚ÄúUnable to authorize user‚Äù by shell.py, therefore
this is a weak feedback to the real problem that is happening, given who
raised this error is httpclient.py (AuthorizationFailure Exception) with a
better message ‚ÄúCurrent authorization does not have a known management url‚Äù
but this one is suppressed by the message in shell.py, so to solve this bug
is possible to attempt to use the auth_url as management_url.

Change-Id: Icbdb0fda3fb7f6e9e1be95c7938b941af2bb2932
'}]
commit_message:
Use auth_url as mgmt_url if not admin identity

When admin identity endpoint is not found from the returned service catalog,
the given message error is ‚ÄúUnable to authorize user‚Äù by shell.py, therefore
this is a weak feedback to the real problem that is happening, given who
raised this error is httpclient.py (AuthorizationFailure Exception) with a
better message ‚ÄúCurrent authorization does not have a known management url‚Äù
but this one is suppressed by the message in shell.py, so to solve this bug
is possible to attempt to use the auth_url as management_url.

Change-Id: Icbdb0fda3fb7f6e9e1be95c7938b941af2bb2932

commit_message:
Use auth_url as mgmt_url if not admin identity

When admin identity endpoint is not found from the returned service catalog,
the given message error is ‚ÄúUnable to authorize user‚Äù by shell.py, therefore
this is a weak feedback to the real problem that is happening, given who
raised this error is httpclient.py (AuthorizationFailure Exception) with a
better message ‚ÄúCurrent authorization does not have a known management url‚Äù
but this one is suppressed by the message in shell.py, so to solve this bug
is possible to attempt to use the auth_url as management_url.
https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-keystoneclient/+bug/1208991

Change-Id: Ic5f1cf9abbcd17fbc665ff532b2025de39c05a4c

the given message error is ‚ÄúUnable to authorize user‚Äù by shell.py, therefore
this is a weak feedback to the real problem that is happening, given who
raised this error is httpclient.py (AuthorizationFailure Exception) with a
better message ‚ÄúCurrent authorization does not have a known management url‚Äù
but this one is suppressed by the message in shell.py, so to solve this bug
is possible to attempt to use the auth_url as management_url.
https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-keystoneclient/+bug/1208991

Change-Id: Ie3b17ca44fd0a36d932693e9f662dc0fa7a2016b

commit_message:
Flavor name should not contain only white spaces

Returns 400 Bad request instead of 200 Ok if flavor name
contains only whitespaces.
Flavor name containing any leading and trailing whitespaces will be
trimmed before validation and before saving it to the backend.

Added unit test cases for both v2 and v3 api's. For v3 api instead of
stubbing flavors 'create' method stubbed db's 'flavor_create' method.
Also removed redundant code of stubbing 'flavor_create' method.

For example
name = "  "              #not allowed
name = "extra large"     #allowed
name = " extra large "   #allowed, but leading and trailing whitespaces
                         #will be trimmed (same as instance name)

Closes-Bug: #1237611

Change-Id: Ie68be299030a878a752dbfdcdfe5094f8427598a

This definitely needs some improvements:
1) We do a delete operation without task status verification. Cause of this we may accidentally delete task that is currently running and cause a data corruption.
2) More general question is why we use "soft_delete" concept? I don't see any real use of this concept and I would prefer to see it completely removed from the project. IMHO delete means delete and it should be clear that it destroys data. There should be no soft or hard delete

from discussion with Boris:
We should check task status before deletion.
--force flag should be used to delete task without status check

Ammend to the point @2:
I think that delete method should use hard delete since soft delete will be removed in the future.'}, {'account_id': 1531, 'date': '2013-10-28 13:58:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Delete task by command

The task is removed together with related results. In addition to the
removal operation the change contains atomistic DB API method to
retrieve results of a task.

bp cli-task-improve

Change-Id: I58f10e28a8d12a63f903bb26b2ef464719ad8f0b

All actions in this table are still to be implemented (currently there
are stubs there).

Also some mechanism of value extraction from table should be
implemented (to actually select new files for a given service, as well
as add some files to a Service that doesn't exist yet).

Change-Id: Ia49edf186c22bbf443b51e70fb8cbac72e710e2a
"}]
commit_message:
Integrate 'Metadata Objects' table into 'Compose Service' form.

All actions in this table are still to be implemented (currently there
are stubs there).

Also some mechanism of value extraction from table should be
implemented (to actually select new files for a given service, as well
as add some files to a Service that doesn't exist yet).

Change-Id: Ia49edf186c22bbf443b51e70fb8cbac72e710e2a

commit_message:
Replace assertEquals with assertEqual

To comply with the new hacking>=0.8.0,<0.9 requirements,
assertEqual is used instead of assertEquals which has been deprecated,
giving the error H234.

Change-Id: I3cbef1353260aec1502114010e12d0e507376389

and linuxbridge will be depreciated going forward to Icehouse.

Change-Id: I4aff2f647c8e0b0ae4014467290482e9ca351386
'}, {'created': '2013-11-05 23:02:26.000000000', 'message': 'Adding ml2 support to baremetal.

Changes the neutron plugin and router to neutron ml2. The Modular
Layer 2 (ml2) plugin is a framework allowing OpenStack Networking
to simultaneously utilize the variety of layer 2 networking
technologies. It currently works with the existing openvswitch,
linuxbridge, and hyperv L2 agents, and is intended to replace
and deprecate the monolithic plugins associated with those L2
agents.

Change-Id: I4aff2f647c8e0b0ae4014467290482e9ca351386
'}]
commit_message:
Adding ml2 support to baremetal.

Changes the neutron plugin and router to neutron ml2. The Modular
Layer 2 (ml2) plugin is a framework allowing OpenStack Networking
to simultaneously utilize the variety of layer 2 networking
technologies. It currently works with the existing openvswitch,
linuxbridge, and hyperv L2 agents, and is intended to replace
and deprecate the monolithic plugins associated with those L2
agents.

Change-Id: I4aff2f647c8e0b0ae4014467290482e9ca351386

commit_message:
Replace assertEquals with assertEqual

To comply with the new hacking>=0.8.0,<0.9 requirements,
assertEqual is used instead of assertEquals which has been deprecated,
giving the error H234.

Change-Id: I96a52d8edc83dc6628ef4e2155649c1f3b2d2f99

commit_message:
Further refactor DataField class and related machinery.

Make it possible to pass an existing DataTable class to the DataField.
Also add `js_buttons' keyword to DataField to control custom js
buttons.

Change-Id: I4d2beb4fb3b5c3b8d2dba1413e9dc0cbcf4cae15

messages:

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGit#Test_Failures

- gate-solum-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/59/55359/1/check/gate-solum-pep8/27d10f9 : SUCCESS in 36s
- gate-solum-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/59/55359/1/check/gate-solum-python26/613b56d : SUCCESS in 50s
- gate-solum-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/59/55359/1/check/gate-solum-python27/a48fce4 : SUCCESS in 44s
- gate-solum-python33 http://logs.openstack.org/59/55359/1/check/gate-solum-python33/2e74d73 : FAILURE in 26s
- gate-solum-pypy http://logs.openstack.org/59/55359/1/check/gate-solum-pypy/f9a7630 : FAILURE in 1m 22s
"}, {'account_id': 8005, 'date': '2013-11-06 08:16:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm currently email-less, so in lieu of an email thread reply, this should illustrate what a basic pecan REST API might look like.  I've added this in response to Russell's request for it in:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-November/018215.html

...to serve as a comparison to Jay's Falcon patchset at:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/55040/5

This basic implementation doesn't include any WSME - that would likely come later when the structure of the API starts to take form.

I'm not certain if YAML is actually wanted/needed by the Solum folks, or if Jay just intended to demonstrate the capability of different API output formats.  Either way, the YAML implementation I've provided in this patchset would probably make more sense as a renderer in a future version of pecan.

Also, if there's any shortcomings in pecan that would make it less desirable for use with Solum (or any project), feel free to let me know :)."}, {'account_id': 8334, 'date': '2013-11-06 08:31:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This is a duplicate of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/55083/"}, {'account_id': 8005, 'date': '2013-11-06 08:34:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Haha, this is what I get for not checking.  I'll take a peek :) at that review and lend my thoughts."}, {'account_id': 8005, 'date': '2013-11-06 08:34:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 8005, 'date': '2013-11-06 08:34:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]

missing Fedora/RHEL/CentOS instructions.

(cherry picked from commit 68c604146687951eee528215cdb40d8ce83a41d2)

commit_message:
Replace assertEquals with assertEqual - tests/scheduler

The method assertEquals has been deprecated since python 2.7.
http://docs.python.org/2/library/unittest.html#deprecated-aliases

Also in Python 3, a deprecated warning is raised when using assertEquals
therefore we should use assertEqual instead.

This is part of blueprint assertequal

Change-Id: I5a6c6ac5d248ea1666f93196d21eb23e793b36d1

missing Fedora/RHEL/CentOS instructions.

commit_message:
xenapi: check for IP address in live migration pre check

A requirement for live migration is that the destination
host contains a management PIF with an IP address assigned.
If a host is broken (no IP), the compute log simply shows a generic
exception on the xenapi call host.migrate_receive.  We can
provide better information that the IP address is missing
by checking this prior to the call.

Closes-Bug: 1245592

Change-Id: Iaa6345f4bddf2f98efb4a5c9743da16ba8ae7b56

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-04 19:09:46.000000000', 'message': "Specifics for Debian install of Cinder

This patch reviews the installation procedure for Cinder
in the Debian install-guide. It also moves the part which
explains how to setup the volume group on top of the
procedure, since that's ok for all operating systems, and
that's needed for Debian (a volume group must be present
before installing cinder-volume, otherwise it will not
be detected automatically, which adds more manual work).

Change-Id: I84914a3447664f70e0c5678f0445b9385ae3b8c8
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit 0d7f0a6422b3a0e518b0d061f40bead9f1ad5d45)
"}]
commit_message:
Specifics for Debian install of Cinder

This patch reviews the installation procedure for Cinder
in the Debian install-guide. It also moves the part which
explains how to setup the volume group on top of the
procedure, since that's ok for all operating systems, and
that's needed for Debian (a volume group must be present
before installing cinder-volume, otherwise it will not
be detected automatically, which adds more manual work).

Change-Id: I84914a3447664f70e0c5678f0445b9385ae3b8c8
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit 0d7f0a6422b3a0e518b0d061f40bead9f1ad5d45)

commit_message:
Fix wrong keyword in glance config file example

- in glance-api.conf, qpid_host becomes qpid_hostname

Change-Id: I326030f48f00ce61334a4e8ff7edf22b1ca8a527
Closes-Bug: 1245851
backport: none

commit_message:
Remove live_snapshot plumbing

This was never actually used.  We discussed the feature this was for on
the mailing list extensively, and then again at the design summit.
Consensus is that this is not something we want to support.

Change-Id: I1dc0a1daa0667b3541f9e397abb2c9b1ea85f55e

commit_message:
Install Guide: Clarify package installation

Clarify the package installation so that it's clear that the
instructions should be complete and no further tweaking is needed.

Change-Id: I0e829e5f569a47e92f3e83c3f44d98eb99ccd0e9
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1245928
(cherry picked from commit b1b2116bcf6427b89c3c5d82b2228ed164addab3)

commit_message:
Adds Database Configuration Support for Havana

Previously, database configuration information was stored in the
plugin .ini file.  As of Havana, a [database] section has been
created in neutron.conf to manage the database configuation for
all Neutron plugins:

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/stable/havana/etc/neutron.conf#L315

Additionaly, several database flags have changed from Grizzly to
Havana.  For backwards compatibility, the previously supported
database flags are contained in neutron::server with a default
of false.

Change-Id: I300fc12092bca1abdd105e0c0c272f7fd49258ac

commit_message:
Ensure keystone endpoint set before service starts

This patch ensures that in the case where keystone and
nova-api are on the same node, nova-api is not started
until the keystone catalog contains the compute service
and endpoint required to use nova.

Change-Id: Ia49874a01582802ba457c9117747aeff203590c3

commit_message:
Ensure keystone endpoint set before service starts

This patch ensures that in the case where keystone and
glance-api are on the same node, nova-api is not started
until the keystone catalog contains the image service
and endpoint required to use glance.

Change-Id: I48ae07b2d7789d549a4412a21e842a1222a48caa

Add Climate Stackforge project

Climate is a new Stackforge project aiming to deliver a Reservation
system for Openstack both virtual instances and physical hosts.

(1 inline comment)

Lana, thanks for your first patch!

Just two quick comments: Please do not introduce extra whitespace, I marked the lines.

Also, your commit message should follow the conventions of:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages

The bug line is separate line of its own and if this fixes a bug write:
Closes-Bug: #1121866

The first line is the title and should not contain a bug reference

Could you update the patch, please?"}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2013-10-29 07:11:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

- check-grenade-devstack-vm http://logs.openstack.org/77/52877/1/check/check-grenade-devstack-vm/5bdfb81 : SUCCESS in 43m 53s
'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-10-21 21:25:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there a reason the existing CHANGELOG file cannot be used? It provides much better information than the proposed output of pbr (which is really just `git shortlog`). I'm a strong proponent of hand-curated change logs since it offers a way to group related changes and provide emphasis to more important changes.

Is the issue only that pbr is creating a "ChangeLog" file (and for case-insensitive file systems)? Of course, and rename of the existing CHANGELOG will have the side effect of breaking existing published links.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-10-27 19:58:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with John; sounds like pbr's ChangeLog should be suppressed and the hand-crafted, higher-quality CHANGELOG used instead."}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-10-28 13:55:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The existing CHANGELOG file can not be used because it does not contain git commit hashes. We use the pbr generated ChangeLog (which indeed is just a git short-log output) for determining which (if any) commits have been merged since the last time we synced the tarball. 

I think NEWS files are pretty standard accross many open source projects to contain high leval, manually maintained news items for new versions, and for that reason alone I think renaming CHANGELOG to NEWS is a good idea. 

I can adjust existing links to CHANGELOG to point to NEWS if we assume to switch to that instead.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-10-28 14:06:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

The existing published links are places like mailing list posts, blog posts, etc that have been using the CHANGELOG for the past three years to track what's going on in Swift releases.

Also, note that the ChangeLog generation is turned off in Swift's setup.cfg. PBR isn't actually generating a changelog (or authors) file for Swift at all."}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-10-29 12:55:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The question is if that shouldn't be changed to be more standard than the rest of OpenStack."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-06 06:03:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-06 06:03:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Rename CHANGELOG to NEWS and package ChangeLog

As part of pbr's sdist, a git-commit ChangeLog is being generated,
that is useful for packagers that consume the git tarballs. Rename
the manually maintained CHANGELOG to NEWS to avoid naming issues
on case insensitive filesystems.

Change-Id: I1930213a8ad6f5f64f0721f8d9dad3f090ee3390
Fixes-Bug: 1186518

'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2013-10-24 12:24:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Oh, I didn't know that OpenStack pass Unicode strings to ValueError or TypeError constructor. I am not sure that it is safe to always cast the exception to a text string to get the message. str(ValueError(u'\xe9')) and unicode(ValueError(b'\xe9')) both fail with unicode errors.

OpenStack needs maybe a function in Oslo to cast arbitrary to text string. See for example the exceptionAsUnicode() I wrote:
http://ufwi.org/projects/edw-svn/repository/revisions/master/entry/trunk/src/nucentral/nucentral/common/error.py#L78

It is based on another toUnicode() function:
http://ufwi.org/projects/edw-svn/repository/revisions/master/entry/trunk/src/nucentral/nucentral/common/tools.py#L28"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-10-24 12:35:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Calling unicode() seems to work fine:

>>> unicode(ValueError(u'\xe9'))
u'\xe9'
>>> sys.version_info
sys.version_info(major=2, minor=7, micro=4, releaselevel='final', serial=0)"}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2013-10-24 13:06:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

unicode(ValueError(unicode)) works, but unicode(ValueError(bytes)) and bytes(ValueError(unicode)) may raise a unicode error.'}, {'account_id': 8415, 'date': '2013-10-24 15:10:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

[{'created': '2013-10-18 23:55:10.000000000', 'message': "Avoid encode errors on invalid user create calls.

If the user create call features an invalid password it is normally
surfaced as a BadRequest exception. However, str() was used on the
original exception. That's bad, as if unicode is present the str() call
will raise, resulting in a 500 status code instead of a 400.

Fixes bug 1241877

Change-Id: Iaa59d9cb65af0932ae1e2fc6a9e4cbf88cc520ba

If the user create call features an invalid password it is normally
surfaced as a BadRequest exception. However, str() was used on the
original exception. That's bad, as if unicode is present the str() call

commit_message:
Avoid encode errors on invalid user create calls.

If the user create call features an invalid password it is normally
surfaced as a BadRequest exception. However, str() was used on the
original exception. That's bad, as if unicode is present the str() call
will raise, resulting in a 500 status code instead of a 400.

Fixes bug 1241877

Change-Id: Iaa59d9cb65af0932ae1e2fc6a9e4cbf88cc520ba

commit_message:
(WIP) async import use case

This is a patch containing all the code necessary to do an import of
an image. Not intended to go in as it is and would be split into
multiple patches shortly after FF ends and ported on top of master.
It is also helping to maintain the code without breaking the depending
patches when a change to later one is proposed.

wip for bp async-glance-workers

Change-Id: I879eebcb8d3e0c85db02463b0e6c28d43a90c666

(8 inline comments)

Hi Lorin,

nice work so far. Some suggestions inline. I just looked at Keystone and Neutron for now.

re, Darragh."}, {'account_id': 2448, 'date': '2013-10-28 19:13:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Lorin, A few questions:

1. Who is the audience? What's the purpose of the doc for that audience?
Meaning, does this book intend to help users learn how to use the CLIs,
and then progress to using python directly? Or to provide examples in
python so the user could extrapolate how to make those same calls in other
languages?
2. Lots of examples without any prose to give the user some context and
step them through the examples.
3. Missing conceptual information - what is iPython? What is a virtualenv?
When you instantiate objects for a client, what exactly are you doing? (I
know experienced programmers would know this, but our audience is end
users who start with horizon and the CLIs, and then progress to using the
APIs directly.)
4. Where is Heat?
5. Title of the book isn't right - Most of the information is *reference*
information - how to instantiate objects and use methods against those
objects, and that's already covered  here:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-novaclient/index.html (and on
the other client pages).

Anyway, some clarity around all that would be helpful!"}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2013-10-29 13:37:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi Lorin, don't mean to dissuade you on your effort here, but I do want to put off finding a place for this until after Hong Kong. 

Some feedback as I've been sending it around internally to our software dev kit maintainers here at Rackspace:
It's better than what we've got, and an improvement over the "Programming Compute API" book that we just removed.
It shows the embarrassing inconsistencies we have project-to-project.
The title is a misnomer, it's not about API but closer to SDK. We're having a session about SDKs at the summit in a week.
I'm not convinced it should be a separate book, what we've been talking about is a progression for users, so it probably should be in the end-user guide and not a separate book. Books have admin overhead like comment moderation and build jobs and I don't really want to add another book.
We may need an equivalent for Java devs, PHP devs, .NET devs, node.js, and so on, how would we resource that? 
The audience we had been envisioning could do the progression Diane mentions Dashboard > CLI > SDK, how can we use this content to help people do that? If we decide against a progression approach, how do we serve multiple non-Python programmers?

Just wanted to be sure you know we're reviewing this, and just want to put off placement to make sure it has a plan for maintenance and upkeep and fits the audience vision we have.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2013-10-29 13:45:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Work In Progress

Diane, you had a lot of good questions about this. However, given Anne's comments about augmenting the user guide with SDK docs instead, I think addressing those would be moot at this point.

Anne, based on your comments, I'm going to mark this as WIP for now. Once there's an SDK plan in place, I'll abandon this change post-summit."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-06 06:03:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-06 06:03:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
OpenStack Python API Guide

Introduces a new guide that documents how to use the Python APIs.

Currently in AsciiDoc format. Includes a makefile which converts
to DocBook.

Change-Id: I0a0a45fe3b93c09525961bc11f94d7e7731d47f2

commit_message:
change assert_ to assertTrue

According to http://docs.python.org/2/library/unittest.html
assert_ is a deprecated alias of assertTrue.

Change-Id: I8cea77e8b8016be1dc629ed8f4c06fdc607d9842

commit_message:
Remove vim header from from nova/tests

This can just be set in your vimrc file. Also if set incorrectly gate
will catch this.

Change-Id: Ic5c9c75c90f2538aafb0eb1692f3ecda4e36fc5d

is there any way to apply this fix on the devstack's end? i'd prefer setting environment variables outside of the code as the defaults here are rather conditional (they'll still fail quite easily if deployed on a higher volume env)"}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2013-10-23 22:16:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

removing -1.

i'd still prefer setting this in devstack since defaults here are rather conditional but don't want to hold this back. i tried bumping max_pool_size to 50 and it will still use up all connections so not sure what proper default sizing here is.

see http://paste.openstack.org/show/49269/"}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2013-10-24 06:34:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks, gordc that confirm my guessing, this is a configuration issue. I have discussed with sdague and doug, we conclude that the default sqlalchemy pool configuration that doesn't pass a full tempest run, are bad defaults.

I have found that neutron are already raise the default value too:

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/common/config.py#L104

For the value I have chosen, I have just x2 the defaults and check that works in gate and it works."}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2013-10-24 14:58:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Change sqlalchemy default pool settings

Change the default value for sqlalchemy pool:
* max_pool_size=10
* max_overflow=20

The previous defaults was 5/10 that is not enought to record samples
produced during a full tempest tests.

Fixes bug #1243251

Change-Id: Ib9060b9da66c8dccb66a8db4994236b7da201ea2

Remove vim header from nova/db

This can be set in your vimrc file.  Also if set incorrectly gate will
catch it.

'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-10-29 05:52:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The swift3 midleware is not configured by devstack because it requires a not openstack git repository.
I wonder can it installed via pip or from a distribution package ?

The existing s3 test are able to work if the S3 endpoint configured to  swift3 + s3token.
If the nova configured to use swift3 instead of nova- objectstore it is also able to register images from swift3.'}, {'account_id': 6889, 'date': '2013-10-29 17:09:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@afazekas: Thank for your reply. I've send that patch and realized after that swift3 is not configured in gates Swift pipeline and finally understood that as an thirdparty tool the (s3token+swift3) are not setup in the gate hosts.

Anyway I have some questions do you think there is a solution to perform functional tests of Swift3 on openstack gate or it will never be possible due to its thirdparty status ?

Second even it's not possible to setup (s3token + swift3) in gate do you think this functional test and an improvement of test_s3_(bucket|object) coverage can be accepted in tempest. As those tests and especially this one is design to test (s3token + swift3) ?"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-06 06:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-06 06:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Add functional tests for auth through s3_token

This functional test tests authentication usecases
related to swift3 + s3token middleware.

Change-Id: I73a7ef32cc48ba71291704c2647a5617b4e02442

[{'created': '2013-10-11 20:38:16.000000000', 'message': 'Remove vim header from from nova/virt

This can just be set in your vimrc file.
Just add the following to your vimrc:

au BufRead,BufNewFile *.py,*.pyw set sw=4 ts=4 expandtab textwidth=79
au BufNewFile *.py,*.pyw set fileformat=unix

Change-Id: I6a9842a48b4ebfc0e6a54ae569b37f9740e783ff
'}, {'created': '2013-10-29 16:19:08.000000000', 'message': 'Remove vim header from from nova/virt

au BufNewFile *.py,*.pyw set fileformat=unix

Change-Id: I6a9842a48b4ebfc0e6a54ae569b37f9740e783ff

commit_message:
Remove vim header from from nova/virt

This can just be set in your vimrc file.
Just add the following to your vimrc:

au BufRead,BufNewFile *.py,*.pyw set sw=4 ts=4 expandtab textwidth=79
au BufNewFile *.py,*.pyw set fileformat=unix

Change-Id: I6a9842a48b4ebfc0e6a54ae569b37f9740e783ff

Could we make this a parallel implementation to the current one?

Pull the new Memcache code out into /swift/common/udpmemcache.py, and then have the memcache middleware use a switch to pick between the two?'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-09-06 20:38:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Feel free to ignore this -1, if the previous comment does not make sense to you."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-09-10 10:22:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm not sure I'd like that.  I could certainly overload the existing middleware to choose the memcache client, and I'll do it if it's what the people want.  But this supports different optional configurations and has a different constructor signature.  It'd be two very divergent code paths in the same method, for a not much simpler story."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-09-10 12:39:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

I think this would be nice if this was external in PYPI or something as I am sure people would be other ppl would be interested by it.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-09-10 14:40:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

@Peter, the current implementation (ie using the config as the "switch" seems a simpler way to implement this version of caching middleware

@Mike, can you add a sample proxy config section too, even if it's mostly a copy of the existing memcache one?'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-09-10 16:36:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-10 17:06:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

This is a very important patch and I would like to support it. [{'created': '2013-09-06 03:31:39.000000000', 'message': "UDP memcache client

New cache middleware that uses UDP to talk to memcached.

This will hopefully help with situations where memcache is overwhelemed by TCP
connections before running out of other resources.  Testing will have to occur

It acts as a mostly drop-in replacement for the current memcache client - just
change the cache filter in your proxy config from `memcache` to `udpmemcache`.

and they can happily co-exist in a cluster for testing purposes.

commit_message:
UDP memcache client

New cache middleware that uses UDP to talk to memcached.

This will hopefully help with situations where memcache is overwhelemed by TCP
connections before running out of other resources.  Testing will have to occur
to see how this pans out.

It acts as a mostly drop-in replacement for the current memcache client - just
change the cache filter in your proxy config from `memcache` to `udpmemcache`.

It implements the same hashing scheme, so switching won't cause a cache flush,
and they can happily co-exist in a cluster for testing purposes.

Change-Id: If7bf39309e923d6ec93c9ad99e29775c1dc85e2b

commit_message:
Docker: driver cannot destroy instance because context variable is
missing.

In some case is openstack not able to destroy/remove a instance
completely. The reason for that is that the destroy method in the docker
driver doesn't provide the optional "context" parameter.

Closes-bug: #1245466

Change-Id: I6e4bc2058d1c0f0e16c059e8433a1e74db99fd4d
