There are a couple of issues that I see with this change:

1) This change is overly broad - it aims to fix 2 reported issues under the description of "live migration is not working." I would prefer that each distinct change has its own patch.  This helps those who may be groking the repository's at a later point in time.
2) There are many use cases where VNC should not be listening on all interfaces. It is not OK for us to force VNC to listen on 0.0.0.0. That said, there may be room for us to enable functionality that provides for an "all" bind interface.  And, I would be in favor of that as an option.  Listening on all interfaces is a generic construct; not specific to VNC and/or live migration.
3) If force_config_drive is indeed broken in nova itself, we should simply set the attribute to true by default, place a FIXME comment (with nova LP bug reference), and fix any associated tests.  The change that is being proposed makes it difficult to understand why this is being done.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-06 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-06 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
migration is not working

if vnc_server_listen is bound to specific IP instead of 0.0.0.0,
libvirt cannot start the migrated VM from destination server.
It's because when libvirt migrate vm to other node it doesn't change
the vnc_server_listen port.

the 'force_config_drive' setting issue has also issue.
this option will be turned on though you set this as false.
(It's because of openstack nova's error)
and it's blocking migration from working because libvirt
also doesn't send the config_disk to the destination node
with having information in libvirt's XML data.

So, these two configs is making the live migration feature failed.

Closes-Bug: #1240759

Change-Id: Ic405cff751ddea56b0eaaf67f296e68845665fcc

[{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2013-09-27 19:12:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

OpenStack uses pbr for its projects. It brings several things, most specifically support for tag-based versioning. It also allows us to share setup code in library form."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-09-27 19:25:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I feel that working on most operating systems is more important than tag-based versioning, at least in a client library we expect to be widely distributed.  The two goals are currently in conflict.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-27 19:29:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-10-01 18:50:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I've personally burnt some cycles chasing down this "headache", and I would love to understand the full impact of removing it - because the benefit seems obvious.

Unfortunately, I don't think "it makes it easier in some situations" or "it causes problems in some situations" is getting anyone the "compelling reasons" we so desperately need.

In *this* case it seems like this change fixes a real bug?

"Can't install python-swiftclient on Distro XYZ" - then we'd need some steps to reproduce.  Can you also update the commit message to reference the bug?

On the other side, there was a nebulous claim that PBR was part of a longer-term effort to make the CI environment more stable - which is certainly a worthy goal I do not wish to impede.  OTOH, https://review.openstack.org/#/c/49206/ seems entirely untenable - so maybe the entire effort was a non-starter?'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-10-07 06:30:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Do not merge

Based on the current status of the openstack-ci system, this cannot be merged at the current time. I'm working on getting more detailed information on both what is breaking and what pbr is solving. We need specifics on the issues encountered (pastebins, bug reports, etc) and how pbr is solving problems in the CI system and for others.

With this information, and accounting for the project's CI infrastructure, we should be able to find a reasonable path forward.

Information on how deployers can bypass pbr during the build step is at http://docs.openstack.org/developer/pbr/packagers.html

Marking as -2 since full information hasn't been provided (from either side)."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-10-07 07:11:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

If you install lucid, "apt-get install python-pip", then "pip install python-swiftclient", it fails and prints out an ugly stack trace.  If you remove the pbr dep, it works fine.

It's a client library, and I'd prefer it to work all over the place with minimal dependencies and weirdness.'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-10-07 15:02:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm a bit curious to hear how removing pbr would somehow break CI.  All of this still sounds very hand wavy to me.  And again I want to stress that the question should be:

Why should pbr be in swift*?

That question has yet to be answered.  I would like to restate, that if it provides little to no benefit, then I see no reason to make it a dependency."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-10-08 16:40:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Please update the commit message to reference the Bug #1236947'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-10-09 02:53:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-10-09 02:53:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

- check-swift-devstack-vm-functional http://logs.openstack.org/24/48724/6/check/check-swift-devstack-vm-functional/35eff66 : SUCCESS in 11m 12s
'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-10-09 04:27:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

We have a real honest to goodness reproducible bug (albeit with a workaround) that I think should be fixed and this patch that fixes it.  Seems like a net win.

I appreciate the -2 while we get some more info, but in the meantime I think redbo's done a pretty good job defining a reasonable problem/solution with this change set.

So help me out here cause I'm failing to see the downside?  http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115082/quotes?item=qt0302617

I'm not really sure the cost of giving up tag based versioning - we do push tags to *our* github repo when we build packages just to keep ourselves sane; but then we use the pbr override environment vars too - that's just our own personal mess.  On the upstream repo notmyname has always managed the authors/changelog/up-rev change for us best I remember, so it was easy for *me*, and now he presumably some how does the push a signed tag to gerrit dance - which I guess seems to be working and is maybe easier for him?  But I have no idea."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-10-13 18:49:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: No score

Removing -2 so that it doesn't get reaped. We'll probably be discussing this next week in person.

Tag-based versioning: nice, but not a deciding factor either way. It's the mashed potatoes to the steak of a good library.

PBR adds tools for consistency across openstack code repos. Right now, it's our ante for openstack. I'd like to see the dependencies go down for a client library. Ideally, pbr as a standalone tool (like debuild for .debs) would be nice."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-10-29 22:54:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Do not merge

For now, keep pbr in swift client.

1) The distro version of pip in Lucid is insecure and shouldn't be used

2) To get python-swiftclient working on Lucid without installing pbr:

sudo apt-get purge python-pip # get rid of the insecure version of pip
sudo easy_install pip # install a recent version of pip
PBR_VERSION=<version> python ./setup.py {develop|install}

If, however, you have pbr installed, the env var above isn't needed. And if you have a recent pip installed, pbr probably doesn't cause too much issue. Packagers can follow the instructions at http://docs.openstack.org/developer/pbr/packagers.html to bypass pbr and build packages.

This being the current state of things, the openstack-infra team wants pbr, packagers can easily work around it, and end-users using (recent, ie secure) pip will have no issues. Unless new issues are brought to light, pbr stays for now."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-10-29 23:41:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

If we're going to pretend that we're not supporting older versions of pip because it's insecure and we know what's best for people, we shouldn't support the pip included with Lucid either.

The real question to me is why pip has to be installed at all.  Everything seemed to work just fine as a normal package up until a couple of months ago."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-10-30 00:13:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Also, using easy_install to upgrade pip because you're worried about MITM attacks is stupid.  It has the EXACT SAME problem.  You should download the setuptools tarball with something that validates certs, then install it, then use that easy_install to install pip."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-06 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-06 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
remove pbr requirement

On some operating systems with older versions of pip, pbr prevents installation
of swiftclient.  Or at least installing it isn't as straightforward as
"pip install python-swiftclient".

For a public client library, I think portability and simplicity of install
should trump whatever ci goals pbr is chasing.

I understand we'll lose tag-based versioning.  I personally don't think it's
worth the headache.

Closes-Bug: #1236947
Change-Id: I352acc5915c250145741ce7d2ba07a7327adf751

commit_message:
Changes Flavors API v2,v3/flavors/{flavor_id} call

This patch changes Flavors API v2,v3/flavors/{flavor_id} call to
not return a flavor that is set as deleted.

[{'created': '2013-11-06 02:42:20.000000000', 'message': "Fix segment range in N1KV test to remove overlap

Adjusts a segment range in an N1KV unit test so
it doesn't overlap with a segment range in another
test that may be executed simultaneously.

Closes-Bug: #1248377
Change-Id: I84a15a2c772f01d7be7ba91aa86de09b934ef5e9
"}]
commit_message:
Fix segment range in N1KV test to remove overlap

Adjusts a segment range in an N1KV unit test so
it doesn't overlap with a segment range in another
test that may be executed simultaneously.

Closes-Bug: #1248377
Change-Id: I84a15a2c772f01d7be7ba91aa86de09b934ef5e9

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-30 03:54:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fail quickly if file injection for boot volume

Previously if the user attempted file injection on a booted volume it
would fail and retry several times, which slowed down the instance
spawning.  Instead of attempting file injection, fail quickly, and
log a warning

Fix bug 1188543

Change-Id: I264540de736c2bcb92567826fe5ba672e1244ba2
(cherry picked from commit f59c2d64ac8f0523c587e23b2d1c59fdfe7ea131)
'}]
commit_message:
Fail quickly if file injection for boot volume

Previously if the user attempted file injection on a booted volume it
would fail and retry several times, which slowed down the instance
spawning.  Instead of attempting file injection, fail quickly, and
log a warning

Fix bug 1188543

Change-Id: I264540de736c2bcb92567826fe5ba672e1244ba2
(cherry picked from commit f59c2d64ac8f0523c587e23b2d1c59fdfe7ea131)

commit_message:
Adds O'Reilly Early Edition output for free download

- Adds epub, mobi, pdf built by O'Reilly toolchain
- Keeps our HTML output for reading and linking
- Links to O'Reilly site

Change-Id: I2a720da4fc7c991c86b79977154f12190ad3f2f2

commit_message:
reset content to resolve upstream depency issue

reset to zero to clear the content for inclusion of the aptira
content replacing the basic install guide content which was
depricated.

Change-Id: Ic464b7124a40984bab685352657a8bb51bd0b5dd
Implements: bp/training-manuals

Mark, thanks for pointing that out in the review. Quite surprising to see that 

  glance-cache-manage help

and

  glance-cache-manage help list-cached

use different methods for determining the help string. I've changed it more to back to the previous output. Readding the  initial new line is difficult, but IMHO the new output looks  
nicer even: 


  $ python -m glance.cmd.cache_manage help list-cached
  cache_manage.py list-cached [options]

  List all images currently cached.
  
  $"}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-10-18 15:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-18 15:58:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Start using PyFlakes and Hacking

Instead of globally ignoring Pyflakes and Hacking
warnings, blacklist explitly only those that trigger
numerously. Fix the rest alongway and start to gate
on those that are now passing.

Change-Id: Ia19dc708cf0ccab2da5b46d1652f16e901499c24

subject: Clean up use of global conf vars in start_nova

commit_message:
Clean up use of global conf vars in start_nova

Make it clear which services run in the API cell and compute (child)
cells by using appropriately named local variables for the conf files.
This should help save from future bugs.

Also: When cells is enabled, there's no need to run nova-conductor in
the API cell right now.  Cells bypasses any use of conductor in the API
cell.

Change-Id: I3af17d3db028f5df36814cb83c7db4de8f141f84

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-05 05:12:31.000000000', 'message': 'Bugfix tempurl role restriction

The tempurl can be and should be enabled on all proxy servers.  When
restricted to just the management server, and requests are loadbalanced
among all proxy servers, the majority of tempurl requests will fail as
they will reach non-management servers.

Change-Id: Icae42a3c44c17251c3cebff3a9c4e05dc36990f7
'}]
commit_message:
Bugfix tempurl role restriction

The tempurl can be and should be enabled on all proxy servers.  When
restricted to just the management server, and requests are loadbalanced
among all proxy servers, the majority of tempurl requests will fail as
they will reach non-management servers.

Change-Id: Icae42a3c44c17251c3cebff3a9c4e05dc36990f7

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-04 19:39:20.000000000', 'message': 'Bugfix allow_override spacing in proxy template

The white space at the beginning of the line in the allow_override
setting can end up being associated with the swauth url on the
preceeding line.  Removing the extra and unnecesary white space
resolves the issue.

Change-Id: I1ccb731cfb7a7a39b7b5026be345a6d50202930c
'}]
commit_message:
Bugfix allow_override spacing in proxy template

The white space at the beginning of the line in the allow_override
setting can end up being associated with the swauth url on the
preceeding line.  Removing the extra and unnecesary white space
resolves the issue.

Change-Id: I1ccb731cfb7a7a39b7b5026be345a6d50202930c

[{'created': '2013-11-01 16:15:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fedora/CentOS specific fixes in devstack engine

Got following issues with Fedora and CentOS:

 * only tcp port 22 is open by default
 * requiretty is true in sudoers
 * no /sbin in $PATH

Change-Id: I7467864059512c1aee2645c0cba46a80db7a055b
'}]
commit_message:
Fedora/CentOS specific fixes in devstack engine

Got following issues with Fedora and CentOS:

 * only tcp port 22 is open by default
 * requiretty is true in sudoers
 * no /sbin in $PATH

Change-Id: I7467864059512c1aee2645c0cba46a80db7a055b

[{'created': '2013-10-30 11:35:29.000000000', 'message': 'Add sleep_between() method to benchmark scenarios

This patch adds a helper sleep_between() method to the base.Scenario class
thus enabling the subscenarios to use it. The method performs a time.sleep()
call for a random amount of seconds from the given range and also counts the
amount of seconds slept to take them to account while calculating the running
time of a scenario.

Here also the NovaServers.boot_and_delete_server gets changed using the new
sleep_between method(): it can now (optionally) perform a sleep between
booting and deleting a server.

Blueprint benchmark-scenarios

commit_message:
Add sleep_between() method to benchmark scenarios

This patch adds a helper sleep_between() method to the base.Scenario class
thus enabling the subscenarios to use it. The method performs a time.sleep()
call for a random amount of seconds from the given range and also counts the
amount of seconds slept to take them to account while calculating the running
time of a scenario.

Here also the NovaServers.boot_and_delete_server gets changed using the new
sleep_between method(): it can now (optionally) perform a sleep between
booting and deleting a server.

Blueprint benchmark-scenarios

Change-Id: I2a76dadbd8413cef0650c2af7cf5125188cb35ba

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-05 12:29:59.000000000', 'message': 'Fix swift_test_client duplicating request params

Remove extra lines of code that result in
swift_test_client adding params twice to
PUT request urls.

Bug was revealed while developing functional
tests for SLO - SLO manifest PUTs behave incorrectly
because the url constructed by swift_test_client ends
with ?multipart-manifest=put?multipart-manifest=put

Fixes bug 1248121

Change-Id: Ie5a8651a55049bb52ef641edfd6eb29b0ff3c245
'}]
commit_message:
Fix swift_test_client duplicating request params

Remove extra lines of code that result in
swift_test_client adding params twice to
PUT request urls.

Bug was revealed while developing functional
tests for SLO - SLO manifest PUTs behave incorrectly
because the url constructed by swift_test_client ends
with ?multipart-manifest=put?multipart-manifest=put

Fixes bug 1248121

Change-Id: Ie5a8651a55049bb52ef641edfd6eb29b0ff3c245

[{'created': '2013-11-05 22:24:09.000000000', 'message': "Stop ignoring jenkins -1 votes

One of the age calculations is the time patches have been up without any
-1 or -2 votes.  This calculation basically just doesn't reset the timer
if a reviewer rebases their change, or fixes some things before anyone
points it out.

Originally I ignored jenkins here.  It really wasn't a good idea.  If
jenkins gives a -1 vote, people are not likely to go review it, so those
votes should be included here.

Change-Id: Iec8deac21a2cfc07bf23e0d0d75e8ea0a27646af
"}]
commit_message:
Stop ignoring jenkins -1 votes

One of the age calculations is the time patches have been up without any
-1 or -2 votes.  This calculation basically just doesn't reset the timer
if a reviewer rebases their change, or fixes some things before anyone
points it out.

Originally I ignored jenkins here.  It really wasn't a good idea.  If
jenkins gives a -1 vote, people are not likely to go review it, so those
votes should be included here.

Change-Id: Iec8deac21a2cfc07bf23e0d0d75e8ea0a27646af

commit_message:
Added options to control sqlalchemy's DB pools.

Sites under heavier load may want to modify the default DB
pool settings. These are stored in the individual plugin inis,
so that is where they have been added.

Change-Id: I99c151ad0de85997bee78227825a53312127fefa

commit_message:
Filter valid networks to appear in create instance modal dialog

We cannot create a instance without assigning it a valid network
subnet. Therefore we present in the dialog the networks that
have a valid subnet.

Change-Id: I35e781041e8957d52b9ec974ac5507e593a793f5
Fixes Bug #1237711

Clean up the code by removing a variable that was used once.

Change-Id: I4c817702e39156619b8d6e17fd1ec022fde034e3

'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-11-02 13:31:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Please follow PEP8 (and PEP257). OpenStack HACKING suggest to follow "PEP8": Read PPE8 and read PEP8 again :-)

The docstring convention PEP257 (referred from PEP8) suggests that multiline docstring should consist of summary line, blank line and detail descriptions. hacking does not require it, but this patch series is a clean up of docstring and it is a good chance to clean up them.

Oneline docstring should be """XXXX""" format. Closing """ should fit into one line.'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2013-11-05 17:07:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Discovering refactoring

Discovering logic has been changed in order to perform some
optimisation. Now discovering process takes place at the time of
ostf-server startup and it loads to db all existing tests.
Also some data from db (test set and corresponding
to them tests data) is cached to provide fast access to this test
repository in future. Further discovering for particualar cluster is
done by adding to database some information that links needed test sets
and tests with cluster. Linking process uses data from cache so
discovering takes less time to be performed.

Change-Id: Ib8ce2c109a216e1e704d2050baaca71f3ad367ad

Discovering refactoring / non major fixes and tests refactoring

For TestRun class from models relationship for test sets via
association_proxy() function was established. It is need because of some
cleaning actions that are performed in standalone TestRun methods by
nose plugin which consume data that is stored in test sets objects.
Unit tests (except those for REST controllers) were updated.
Some additional non-major refactoring was performed.

Change-Id: I94ef205ee6d90426929746573c836f4de7cc7b24

commit_message:
Openstack DbaaS(Database as a Service)/Trove resource

This is patch-1 in the two patch series to implement trove
(DBaaS) resource. This patch adds troveclient to requirements
and updates clients.py to get trove client.

Blueprint dbaas-trove-resource

Change-Id: I7f8b3fad2b47db4ef14686ce9c94955144211c3c

subject: python requirements in docs
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-28 15:44:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-noop http://logs.openstack.org/39/54139/1/check/gate-noop/19fa5ec : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 8787, 'date': '2013-10-28 19:42:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Why is this change necessary, what problem does it solve?

Why is it more preferrable to use a Python specific toola (pip) to install dependencies rather than base OS package management tool (apt)?

If the goal is to extract volatile specifics from the docs, why not create requirements-devel-deb.txt?"}, {'account_id': 8053, 'date': '2013-10-28 20:43:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

First, pip is definitely more preferable, than deb
Second, we need to install specific versions of software, independently of those presented or not presented in OS repos.'}, {'account_id': 8787, 'date': '2013-10-28 21:41:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

That doesn't answer any of my questions. "Definitely" doesn't explain "why", I already see from the patch that you prefer pip over apt, but you did not reference any reasons in your commit message.

Using pip and mixing dependencies on different versions of the same packages in different places keeps causing us trouble, here's the most recent example:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/54118/

This isn't helped by us using an obsolete unsupported version of pip simply because we decided to pin it down instead of fixing the breakage caused by upgrade.

To answer your second point, we already maintain our own repo of deb and rpm packages, and apt allows you to install specific versions of deb packages just as well as pip, e.g.:

 apt-get install python-pbr=0.5.21-1

Our package management is already a mess, having different teams maintaining their own language-specific package management systems, each with its own quirks, only makes it worse. Different teams locking their environments to different library versions even within the same language-specific environment is worse yet. The default should be to move away from this mess, not pushing new developers towards this way of thinking.'}, {'account_id': 8787, 'date': '2013-10-31 17:08:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-11-05 11:00:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.

commit_message:
healthcheck functionality

added test table printing

refactored printing, separated ostf, and api calls

refactored printing again, fixed indent, rewritten a post ostf method

fixed message printing with 'fuel env set'

removed unnessasary get request headers, print_deploy_progress refactored

added try catch to curses printer

Change-Id: Ib973910b56571c3e13b35517c758b6fd39633ca9

commit_message:
Set Nova auth_proto regardless of tls-proxy.

We actually want to comment out the keystone auth_proto in Nova's
api-paste.ini file regardless of the tls-proxy setting. Likewise
lets always set it in nova.conf as well.

This should fix an issue in trying to get this in:

  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/52825/

Change-Id: I1b8202aa1666cbb6ca13d2f77d50fa0175969266

commit_message:
Add Pcloud Flavors

This change introduces the basic framework for creating and managing
pclouds flavors (Host Flavors), which can be used by users to add such
hosts to the Pcloud.

Partly implements blueprint:  whole-host-allocation

Change-Id: Ib45b1f887b576f612ee184584667df48627fb3d3

subject: Fixed issue when '# is required' with 1 instance

Thanks Sridar, I have responded to your comments.'}, {'account_id': 7752, 'date': '2013-08-28 02:00:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I reviewed the code and tested with the new CLI that implements the commit operation.

From user perspective, 'commit' operation is important feature to have (as was agreed by most of us). 

Given that this does not change the semantics of create/update/delete, and 'commit' is exclusively used for resources that needs auditing and staged updates of backend services, I am satisfied with this implementation and I do not think this additional operation would confuse operations on existing resources in Neutron. 

I would like the FWaaS feature to be released with 'commit'operation to make it usable (esp with physical devices and large configs)."}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2013-08-28 07:05:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6995, 'date': '2013-08-28 23:06:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(2 inline comments)

Thanks for answering my queries. The comments on the log are nits and u can pick that up on a subsequent rev or not.

Overall, in the discussions leading to this change, as pointed out by Rajesh - this does not change the underlying semantics but merely increases the usability aspects of the feature. It is beneficial to be able to have the ability to make an atomic change for a set or rules. I do hope that this gets merged into H3 to ease vendor implementations that are being planned for the I release.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-08-30 18:19:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Do not merge

After reading through the proposal and discussing with members of the core team and other deployers within the community, my view is that this proposal does not achieve the following requirements:

1) The running configuration is consistent with the logical configuration
2) Rules and policies can effectively and efficiently audited

Consider the following actions:

1) Tenant creates policy P
2) Tenant creates rule R associated with P
3) Tenant creates firewall F1 with policy P
4) Tenant creates firewall F2 with policy P
5) Tenant updates R so we now have pending rule R'
6) Tenant requests commit for firewall F1
7) Tenant updates R again so we now have pending rule R''
8) Tenant list the rules associated with policy P.  The list will show R'' as a member of the policy rule set.

At this point, the actual firewall state is very difficult to determine and audit because while firewalls F1 and F2 show they have policy P.  Neither is actually actively implementing P as returned to the user.  This is confusing and could be problematic especially when troubleshooting.  A deep inspection of the firewall's detail is the only way to determine what should be applied by a given instance.

There are additional complications:
- When commit is called on F2.  What rule is committed?  R' or R''?
- Remove of R'' from P and call commit on F2.  What happens?  Seems like a deleted rule will be applied to the firewall.
- Multiple instances of neutron require exact time synchronization via NTP.  If there is any clock skew, the behavior is not very clear.

For these reasons, I'm -2 on this change for Havana.  

I'd want to propose the following:
1) We prevent updates to rules that are associated to policies attached to firewalls.
2) We add a command that will do a server side duplication of a policy (this will include duplicating the rules too).  The operation should allow a tenant to specify the new name of the duplicated policy.  A tenant can then make the alterations to the copy and then call update_firewall with the new policy.  This workflow ensures logical consistency, accurate auditing, and also provides a builtin rollback mechanism to the tenant.  This approach should be more RESTful too.
3) We mark the FWaaS API as experimental.  We did this for LBaaS in Grizzly and similarly will position the VPNaaS API this way too.

At the Icehouse summit, we can/should revisit this topic if the above interim solution does not prove workable for the long term."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-08-30 22:28:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

Reading the above response suggests that the original proposal has probably not been entirely understood. 

The new/ad hoc proposal essentially suggests a clone operation on the policy and this was already in the plans. However using a clone operation to create a new policy (when the policy needs to be edited) addresses a different workflow from what is trying to be achieved here. Creating a new copy of the policy every time a rule needs to be added/updated will create a management and auditing headache due to proliferation of the policy copies.

The original proposal was put forward based on feedback obtained in the community from using the first version of the merged API. The response to the proposal within the community was mostly supportive.

We will bring this up for discussion in the summit.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-07 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-07 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 3217, 'date': '2013-11-05 07:31:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Late to the day, but I'd agree with Mark here - firstly the applied state is not necessarily the DB state, and secondly, you can run into issues if you have multiple writers to one firewall where one writer can commit the other's operations (and probably by extension you end up in wierd states if your firewall controller is a multi-VM redundant system).

More appropriate would be something where the entire set of modifications was posted to a special URL and was applied as an atomic operation, so the DB state 'instantly' changes from one state to the other and does it at the same time that the firewall changes state.  It's not very REST either but at least it would be atomic and it doesn't have issues with a problematically large queue of pending ops."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-11-05 08:23:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Ian, perhaps I don't completely understand your concern, but I would encourage you to look at the patch again, each commit/apply operation is indeed atomic."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-11-05 08:41:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

Also I would like to understand what is less or not RESTful in this approach?'}]

This patch introduces a commit operation for the FWaaS firewall.

The commit operation is used to apply changes in rules/policy to
a particular firewall.

There is no change in CRUD semantics for all FWaaS resources including
firewall. Changes to rules/policies will be reflected immediately in
the database (but will not be applied to any associated firewalls
until a commit operation is performed on a particular firewall).

firewall_rule and firewall_policy have a new readonly attribute
update_timestamp.

firewall resource has the following new readonly attributes:
* commit_timestamp
* committed_rules
* policy_modified_commit_required (boolean, this indicates whether the
committed rules on the firewal are in sync with the current state of
the policy).

commit_message:
FWaaS - Firewall Commit Operation Support

This patch introduces a commit operation for the FWaaS firewall.

The commit operation is used to apply changes in rules/policy to
a particular firewall.

There is no change in CRUD semantics for all FWaaS resources including
firewall. Changes to rules/policies will be reflected immediately in
the database (but will not be applied to any associated firewalls
until a commit operation is performed on a particular firewall).

firewall_rule and firewall_policy have a new readonly attribute
update_timestamp.

firewall resource has the following new readonly attributes:
* commit_timestamp
* committed_rules
* policy_modified_commit_required (boolean, this indicates whether the
committed rules on the firewal are in sync with the current state of
the policy).

The associated CLI change is in the following patch:
https://review.openstack.org/43249

blueprint neutron-fwaas-explicit-commit

Change-Id: Ib11d90ec46b7497401d89fcdc65f2d8b10d682b2

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-02 12:54:38.000000000', 'message': 'Debian consitency and links

This patch reviews the "Answer to the debconf" things in
every service, so that they look the same. It also adds
links to the debconf chapter, so that users can navigate
more easily in the doc. Lastly, it also changes the
titles of the debconf chapter so that they match the
text in each chapter. Finally, this patch documents the
fact that python-argparse should be installed manually
on all Wheezy setups, which is an issue that has been
reported by some users, and which wasn't documented.

Change-Id: I5a85f39e49786ae90cc0afbf13b94baf486408f4

commit_message:
Debian consitency and links

This patch reviews the "Answer to the debconf" things in
every service, so that they look the same.

It also adds links to the debconf chapter, so that users
can navigate more easily in the doc.

It also changes the titles of the debconf chapter so that
they match the text in each chapter.

It also documents the fact that python-argparse should be
installed manually on all Wheezy setups, which is an issue
that has been reported by some users, and which wasn't
documented.

The patch also extends the explanations about the
meta-packages.

This patch adds a lot of <informalfigure> tags that were
missing as well.

Finally, the patch also moves the explanation about remote
MySQL setup from the nova installation procedure to the
debconf-dbconfig-common section of the debconf chapter,
which is a much better fit.

This is my last clean-up work, I believe.

Change-Id: I5a85f39e49786ae90cc0afbf13b94baf486408f4
backport: havana

Thanks for picking this up David.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-10-15 12:27:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Migration 227 is now taken."}, {'account_id': 8688, 'date': '2013-10-15 14:23:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-15 15:20:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-nova-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/48/50148/3/check/gate-nova-pep8/044e106 : SUCCESS in 4m 12s

'}, {'account_id': 7069, 'date': '2013-10-17 03:26:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-10-19 21:36:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-10-20 08:53:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-10-25 14:43:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Should these indexes be on 'key' and 'deleted' instead of just 'key'?"}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-10-25 15:05:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

russellb, I agree that we should also add an index on deleted, because models.py primary_join includes "deleted==0"

I'll add that.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-10-25 19:41:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Why is this going to improve performance? I don't think we ever (or at least, hardly ever) query based on system_metadata.key. We've been discussing removing this altogether and replacing it with a JSON blob. I don't think it's worth the *very* large amount of work required to do this migration for folks that currently have large databases, especially if we're just going to replace it soon."}, {'account_id': 8688, 'date': '2013-10-28 10:07:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hi Dan, HP do query this table by key. As it's a key/value table, I'm not sure what else you expected to be done with it?

Without having heard the discussion, I'm -1 to replace it with JSON as then it'd be much harder to use as a query filter.

There's a discussion on the mailing list about long DB migrations. It sounds as though mitigating this has been a long-term ambition however, would you -1 all long migrations until that is resolved? This is not just a hygiene issue for us.

Happy for the index to be (key, deleted) though."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-10-28 14:37:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

"Hi Dan, HP do query this table by key."

Is this being done in some code that you expect to be submitted to Nova?  If not, I don't think we should use that as a reason not to change anything about system metadata.  I consider Nova's database to be a private interface that is subject to being completely changed at any time, and only subject to the code and features that we have in the tree.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-10-28 14:50:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

+1 to putting the deleted column in the index, we've seen the need for that with indexes when running against DB2."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-10-28 14:56:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

As Dan pointed out, this is a change that's going to cause significant db work and potential downtime for a change that doesn't seem to add much benefit to the current query sets.  If there are real issues being seen then please document them as justification rather than having theoretical concerns.

As far as a conversion to JSON blobs go we do have real issues with the amount of data being sent over the wire due to joining instance_system_metadata with the instances table and the fact that there can be 30+ instance_system_metadata rows during a migration.  JSON blobs address that particular issue.  It does make query filtering harder but as of yet there is no query filtering that happens with this data and no known plans to add any.

There are of course different ways to address this problem and it's worth a discussion if a proposed solution conflicts with work that others would like to get done.

But for this particular patch it's not clear to me that the downsides of this migration outweigh the current benefits."}, {'account_id': 8688, 'date': '2013-10-31 08:11:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Propose this is abandoned.

I'm used to 'smart' queries which include a certain amount of logic. The OpenStack approach seems to be client-side caching + processing, which given a distributed arch + heavy use of plugins makes some sense.

My original issue was that the particular plugin I wanted to write didn't receive a metadata blob, forcing the direct DB query. This need has gone away for now; if it arises again, I'll propose supplying that blob."}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-11-05 07:38:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

Multiple votes against, and even Alexis is no longer fighting for it, so abandoning.'}]

After checking current codes, I doubt the issue may only exit in single compute node env, have you tried to produce the issue in multi compute nodes env?"}, {'account_id': 7138, 'date': '2013-10-21 09:31:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

More over, even applying your code changes, it still depends on service list operation to call availability_zones.set_availability_zones to update cache, I think it's better to design and implement an availability zone cache updating mechanism, cache updating shouldn't couple with a specific API, it doesn't make sense."}, {'account_id': 7138, 'date': '2013-10-28 07:18:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I don't think it's worth to do tremendous code changes for az cache, since without timely cache update, az works well. If users can't wait for an hour to see the az info via "nova show", how about only changing AZ_CACHE_SECONDS to be configurable item? Then users can configure the time according to their requirement.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-11-05 06:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Fixing availability-zone not take effect error

when create a availability-zone, add a host to the aggregate,
then boot an instance in the host, "OS-EXT-AZ:availability_zone"
property can not show correctly in time when using "nova show
<server>". The cause is that nova does not update the cache in
time, so should change this to avoid getting old cache.

Closes-bug: #1240374

Change-Id: I2466752912ee030be55776988bfabb40cf3e94b5

commit_message:
Add initial test for db migrations

Dependences: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/42307/ (should be reviewed).

This patch only adds test_migration.py

Partially implements bp: db-sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: If54247bc7a308274e44ec3aafbf403314eadc81d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-24 15:09:38.000000000', 'message': 'Revert default ceilometer storage driver to mongodb

Previously, this was changed to sqlalchemy in order to avoid
an issue with ceilometer requiring mongodb-server >= 2.4.x.

Now, an appropriate version of mongodb is available from the
cloud archive, so we enable this as an additional repository.

Change-Id: I62ce8d8569b123618688f101575615c7ec7914cd
'}]
commit_message:
Revert default ceilometer storage driver to mongodb

Previously, this was changed to sqlalchemy in order to avoid
an issue with ceilometer requiring mongodb-server >= 2.4.x.

Now, an appropriate version of mongodb is available from the
cloud archive, so we enable this as an additional repository.

Change-Id: I62ce8d8569b123618688f101575615c7ec7914cd

print out nova aggregate-details for debug

in order to determine what's going on in the gate, we need to
print out the aggregate-details list to understand how we are
failing.

commit_message:
Use _get_server_admin_password()

There is _get_server_admin_password() for getting an admin password
in ServersController class. This patch makes some methods use it for
code clean-up.

Change-Id: Iff9d960126e1c09d928d72b572838e6f16cc4f33

we can just remove them.

lgtm, other than gary's nit"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-10-17 15:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Gary,

On second thought I actually kind of like leaving these in a block is fine for now. This matches what we do in other services (Neutron/Glance) and consistency seems reasonable here. And my preference is really for these not to be commented out anyway.

If were to make them comments with documentation we could just make our sample file generator actually process keystoneclients authtoken file as well... which is going to put a whole bunch more options in the file as well (it would add around 25 options). Since this file is out of tree I think handling it with a special case (like we do here) is probably better though.

If people really want documentation strings to match the Nova config section I suppose I could inline a one time copy of the selected strings though. Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-10-18 12:27:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-18 13:01:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Add auth_token settings to nova.conf.sample.

Updates our example config file so that it includes configuration
settings for the auth_token middleware.

Includes the latest generate_sample.sh from Oslo.

Related-Bug: #1240753

Change-Id: I393a67f1f005e775928130c9241aa7e25c391ae3

commit_message:
Fix `NoopQuotaDriver.get_(project|user)_quotas` format

The quota API extension expects `get_project_quotas` and `get_user_quotas` to
return a dictionary where the value is another dictionary with a `limit` key.

The `DbQuotaDriver` adhered to this spec, but the `NoopQuotaDriver` didn't.

This fixes the `NoopQuotaDriver` to return the results in the correct format.

Fixes bug 1244842

Change-Id: Iea274dab1c3f10c3cb0a2815f431e15b4d4934b1

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-11 03:52:32.000000000', 'message': 'Remove multipath mapping device descriptor

When detaching a volume from a instance, we need to remove
multipath mapping device descriptor if there are other volumes
mapping to the host instead of do nothing, for some cinder drivers
can not terminate connection for multipath tool sending IOs to
storage array periodically.

Change-Id: I6fc02e045146ece49162ca6be1a83fa8d0214a0a
'}, {'created': '2013-09-11 17:11:30.000000000', 'message': 'Remove multipath mapping device descriptor

When detaching a volume from a instance, we need to remove
multipath mapping device descriptor if there are other volumes
mapping to the host instead of do nothing, for some cinder drivers
can not terminate connection for multipath tool sending IOs to

commit_message:
Remove multipath mapping device descriptor

When detaching a volume from a instance, we need to remove
multipath mapping device descriptor if there are other volumes
mapping to the host instead of do nothing, for some cinder drivers
can not terminate connection for multipath tool sending IOs to
storage array periodically.

Closes-bug: #1223975
Change-Id: I6fc02e045146ece49162ca6be1a83fa8d0214a0a

[{'created': '2013-11-04 18:41:44.000000000', 'message': "Fix unit tests.

Turns out that if a test module's setup() function fails, tox silently
ignores the failures.

There was a bug where the test storage policies were being ignored by
the container controller, thus causing
test.unit.proxy.test_server.setup() to fail. The bug has been fixed.

Change-Id: I73a6f9ad3b1e2d7198d6a7fc67a0fbfd9116d684
"}]
commit_message:
Fix unit tests.

Turns out that if a test module's setup() function fails, tox silently
ignores the failures.

There was a bug where the test storage policies were being ignored by
the container controller, thus causing
test.unit.proxy.test_server.setup() to fail. The bug has been fixed.

Change-Id: I73a6f9ad3b1e2d7198d6a7fc67a0fbfd9116d684

we can utilize that.

commit_message:
Add a better installer for local Barbican application instances.

The current local installer (bin/barbican-all) requires that users
perform several steps before hand. The new installer seeks to minimize
the amount of manual steps needed.

Change-Id: Ie5d74331028fa7c463f53bed92a504771c09a385
Implements: blueprint add-local-installer-script

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-04 20:35:57.000000000', 'message': 'Fix deprecation warning.

BaseException.message is deprecated; if you have an exception of type
Exception (or subclass thereof), then "str(ex)" is the preferred way
to get the message.

Change-Id: I5b4acf88de538c1ef0f2db4fefaa92699937cd50
'}]
commit_message:
Fix deprecation warning.

BaseException.message is deprecated; if you have an exception of type
Exception (or subclass thereof), then "str(ex)" is the preferred way
to get the message.

Change-Id: I5b4acf88de538c1ef0f2db4fefaa92699937cd50

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-02 07:21:10.000000000', 'message': "Specifics for Debian install of Cinder

This patch reviews the installation procedure for Cinder
in the Debian install-guide. It also moves the part which
explains how to setup the volume group on top of the
procedure, since that's ok for all operating systems, and
that's needed for Debian (a volume group must be present
before installing cinder-volume, otherwise it will not

commit_message:
Specifics for Debian install of Cinder

This patch reviews the installation procedure for Cinder
in the Debian install-guide. It also moves the part which
explains how to setup the volume group on top of the
procedure, since that's ok for all operating systems, and
that's needed for Debian (a volume group must be present
before installing cinder-volume, otherwise it will not
be detected automatically, which adds more manual work).

Change-Id: I84914a3447664f70e0c5678f0445b9385ae3b8c8
backport: havana

commit_message:
Install Guide: Clarify package installation

Clarify the package installation so that it's clear that the
instructions should be complete and no further tweaking is needed.

Change-Id: I0e829e5f569a47e92f3e83c3f44d98eb99ccd0e9
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1245928

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-28 13:44:51.000000000', 'message': 'compute tests: replace assertEquals with assertEqual

In Python 2.6, both assertEqual and assertEquals are
convenience aliases to failUnlessEqual.

In Python 3, failUnlessEqual is explicitly deprecated.

This is part of blueprint assertequal

Change-Id: Id639655621be04383fac986e8a0dc50a0951b64b
'}, {'created': '2013-11-02 17:30:15.000000000', 'message': 'compute tests: replace assertEquals with assertEqual

assertEquals will be deprecated in Python 3.

This is part of blueprint assertequal

Change-Id: Id639655621be04383fac986e8a0dc50a0951b64b
'}]
commit_message:
compute tests: replace assertEquals with assertEqual

assertEquals will be deprecated in Python 3.

This is part of blueprint assertequal

Change-Id: Id639655621be04383fac986e8a0dc50a0951b64b

commit_message:
Raise 404 exceptions for missing port and network

This just adds the status_code to the exception object as it was
previously available before, providing backwards compatability.

Closes-bug: #1234924
Change-Id: I5647f1d4900648a734f6b18bedcee00f9d6c70b0

commit_message:
edit inheritence tree api/network/security_groups

changed negative tests from "smoke" to "gate"

avoid running "father's" test cases in son
both positive and negative now derive from common TestCase without
"test_" methods

previous:
BaseNetworkTest
	SecGroupTest
		NegativeSecGroupTest

new tree:
BaseNetworkTest
	BaseSecGroupTest
		SecGroupTest
		NegativeSecGroupTest

Change-Id: Ia438b9d0c591c1c250443f6b6d069d41b6d71097

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-22 23:37:18.000000000', 'message': 'Add colon after service name

In Fedora 21 the log format changed from this:

Oct 10 23:54:20 rhev-a24c-01 proxy-server 10.10.55.128 .....

to this:

Oct 10 23:57:49 kvm-rei journal: proxy-server 192.168.128.11 .....

It is clearly incompatible, because the word "journal:" is added.

It happens because all the log messages are filtered by Systemd
and it adds "journal:" if it cannot find a word ending with colon.
See:
 https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1018042

It seems that one simple fix could be in Swift. We already add
the indentifier word, it's just we do not end it in colon.
Therefore, we could start adding a colon to make the log look
more like any other system log.

Unfortunately, this is not entirely compatible either! The number
of words is kept, so if you parse with regexp, you get the things
in expected places, but the name of the server now has a colon.
Would be simple enough to fix, I suppose, but still, this needs
a consideration. Reviewers should feel free to put -1 or -2 on
this if they find an application that breaks with this patch.

Change-Id: I0d641ae49e6fc989283868ade2ca542a8133cb07
'}]
commit_message:
Add colon after service name

In Fedora 21 the log format changed from this:

Oct 10 23:54:20 rhev-a24c-01 proxy-server 10.10.55.128 .....

to this:

Oct 10 23:57:49 kvm-rei journal: proxy-server 192.168.128.11 .....

It is clearly incompatible, because the word "journal:" is added.

It happens because all the log messages are filtered by Systemd
and it adds "journal:" if it cannot find a word ending with colon.
See:
 https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1018042

It seems that one simple fix could be in Swift. We already add
the indentifier word, it's just we do not end it in colon.
Therefore, we could start adding a colon to make the log look
more like any other system log.

Unfortunately, this is not entirely compatible either! The number
of words is kept, so if you parse with regexp, you get the things
in expected places, but the name of the server now has a colon.
Would be simple enough to fix, I suppose, but still, this needs
a consideration. Reviewers should feel free to put -1 or -2 on
this if they find an application that breaks with this patch.

Change-Id: I0d641ae49e6fc989283868ade2ca542a8133cb07

commit_message:
Implements client and tests for Ceilometer V2 api.

Components covered: nova, glance, swift and neutron.
Ceilometer entities coverage: samples, meters, resources, statistics
TODO: alarms, sample posting, advanced nova meters.

Implements: blueprint Add basic tests for Ceilometer
(https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tempest/+spec/add-basic-ceilometer-tests)

Change-Id: I1f20556454145ba203b925a25ec57f6ea05dd112

messages:
[{'account_id': 7858, 'date': '2013-11-01 21:30:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9124, 'date': '2013-11-01 22:05:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 7680, 'date': '2013-11-01 22:08:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

We don't need a contributors file, pbr can auto-generate us an authors from the git log."}, {'account_id': 7858, 'date': '2013-11-01 22:24:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

there was talk on IRC about using it as a way to give a simple walk-thru on using the review process as well as the obvious list keeping.

exampled in wiki - https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Solum/Contributing#Your_first_commit'}, {'account_id': 668, 'date': '2013-11-01 23:34:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I agree to this in concept, but see my comment about giving credit to the other authors already in the commit history. As we are accumulating new developers from outside the OpenStack ecosystem, I think this approach is a good way to orient newcomers to the OpenStack CI experience. Once we feel that we are in a steady state and are not on-boarding much, we should switch to an auto-generated AUTHORS file using pbr, and simplify the Solum/Contributing page at that point."}, {'account_id': 8334, 'date': '2013-11-02 01:38:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I second Alex Gayner in this case.

I think "how to contribute?" doc is comprehensive and easy for everyone to understand. What other use case for this file can we think of other than helping newcomer with his initial patch?'}, {'account_id': 8334, 'date': '2013-11-02 01:43:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Let me ask another question?

How do we know that the patch belongs to a potential contributor?'}, {'account_id': 395, 'date': '2013-11-02 17:51:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

As mentioned PBR does this and also sites like Stackalytics"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-11-03 03:11:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm on the side of thinking it's pretty silly to have this file that can easily be auto-generated.

If you just want to be able to help people get the hang of gerrit.  You can do it with a completely garbage change.  You don't have to merge it.  Ideally only things actually useful get merged ..."}, {'account_id': 7858, 'date': '2013-11-04 15:32:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

redundant information is redundant.

contributors can be programmatically generated via computers.'}]

commit_message:
Adding VM's net ids as a search opt for get_available_networks

Adding VM's net ids as a search option for get_available_networks()
function.
Fixing several neutron nova tests to support the new behavior

Change-Id: I9d93f3f9c0dbf3c882c5afa32c544b9b756abe37
Closes-Bug: #1238129

commit_message:
Fix parsiong of network provider

Patch include fixes:
* Change uri for parsing network_provider
* For create instance method add create_kargs parameter
  with specified network id
* Fix pep8 issues

Fixes bug/1247230 bug/1247082

Change-Id: I154dfec16ee54de33787766f03025840ff15783a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-03 07:21:17.000000000', 'message': "Always pass context to compute driver destroy()

The context arg was added to the compute driver's destroy() method in
commit 8c0673d3102478ef34ef1b11c1db156db4b68f62.  The context is used by
the libvirt driver when dealing with encrypted volumes.

Unfortunately, most of the places where this method is called in the
compute manager, the context wasn't being passed in.  This patch makes
the argument mandatory and updates all of the drivers to match.

Change-Id: Icea2a36c16869af43954065473ff4e4910f32b1e
"}]
commit_message:
Always pass context to compute driver destroy()

The context arg was added to the compute driver's destroy() method in
commit 8c0673d3102478ef34ef1b11c1db156db4b68f62.  The context is used by
the libvirt driver when dealing with encrypted volumes.

Unfortunately, most of the places where this method is called in the
compute manager, the context wasn't being passed in.  This patch makes
the argument mandatory and updates all of the drivers to match.

Change-Id: Icea2a36c16869af43954065473ff4e4910f32b1e

Build succeeded.

- gate-oslo-incubator-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/68/54868/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/e801dfa/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 05s
- gate-oslo-incubator-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/68/54868/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26/553e529 : SUCCESS in 3m 36s
- gate-oslo-incubator-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/68/54868/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/f7b2957 : SUCCESS in 3m 24s
'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-11-04 02:30:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

At least some of these instances are fine - anything that inherits from BaseTestCase doesn't need to clean up its temp files because we're using the NestedTempfile fixture: https://github.com/openstack/oslo-incubator/blob/master/openstack/common/test.py#L33

That said, I'm not sure whether that handles the cases where we specify a /tmp path explicitly instead of using mkstemp.  I don't really think we should be doing that anyway though, so instead of messing with cleaning up those files we should convert the test cases to use mkstemp so we don't have to worry about it."}, {'account_id': 6722, 'date': '2013-11-04 11:41:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ben, thanks for pointing out we are using fixture NestedTempfile. This does not affect temporary file creation where an explicit containing directory was provided. So we have something like "shutil.rmtree('/tmp/testing')" to handle this situation.'}, {'account_id': 6722, 'date': '2013-11-04 11:41:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-01 02:58:25.000000000', 'message': 'Delete temporary files used in tests

We use temporary files created by fileutils.write_to_tempfile.
but never delete them. They are left in system after running test
cases. User of mkstemp() is responsible for deleting the temporary
file when done with it.
See http://docs.python.org/2/library/tempfile.html#tempfile.mkstemp

Change-Id: I809f05286f3233c2f6e040b544f870cba20497f9
'}]
commit_message:
Delete temporary files used in tests

We use temporary files created by fileutils.write_to_tempfile.
but never delete them. They are left in system after running test
cases. User of mkstemp() is responsible for deleting the temporary
file when done with it.
See http://docs.python.org/2/library/tempfile.html#tempfile.mkstemp

Change-Id: I809f05286f3233c2f6e040b544f870cba20497f9

'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-10-16 06:29:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-10-22 20:50:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Why do you use two locks instead of one?  I don't think this is currently deadlock-prone because you always acquire human_id_cache_lock first then uuid_cache_lock while human_id_cache_lock is already held.  But if they're always nested, you don't need two."}, {'account_id': 9049, 'date': '2013-10-22 20:57:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm confused as to why we shouldn't merge this. Currently, python-novaclient is not thread-safe and you can only provision and clean VMs with one thread. At VMware, we already use this patch and it significantly improves provisioning and cleaning time.

As far as the cache locking, this is true about the caches being nested, but we would have to put locks in each function that calls the completion cache which breaks modularity and makes the code less readable."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-10-28 06:09:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Is there a good reason to not have used the locking decorators from oslo-incubator here instead? I ask because we have an existing pattern for locking, and I'd like to stick to it unless there is a good reason not to."}, {'account_id': 9049, 'date': '2013-10-28 16:56:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 9049, 'date': '2013-10-28 16:59:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Addressed David's comments.

Michael, I agree we should use the defined locking scheme, but oslo-incubator is not part of this repository. Is it worth creating this dependency just for locking? If so, do you recommend I use oslo-incubator as a git submodule? Or how do you think I should import the lockutils file?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-28 17:27:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-10-28 18:24:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Um, yes it is.  You may have a misunderstanding about how oslo-incubator is intended to be used; see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Oslo#Incubation for an introduction.  It should just be a matter of adding lockutils to openstack-common.conf (note we like to keep the module list in alphabetical order) and synchronizing the module in.  (Caution here; the sync script may want to update other modules as well, which may have changes that conflict with novaclient.  You should ensure that only lockutils.py (and any of its dependencies) is added in your patch‚Ä¶)'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-10-30 17:39:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Thanks for addressing the redundant lock.

I agree that, since we're synchronizing one whole method, we should use the lockutils decorator for consistency."}, {'account_id': 9049, 'date': '2013-10-30 18:44:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

So after looking at the lockutils module, there doesn't seem to be an RLock implementation (i.e. a thread that previously acquired the lock can acquire it again). Am I correct in assuming this? If I am correct, should I

a) use one lock every time a cache lookup is executed i.e.
    with lockutils.lock('mylock', ...)
        with self.completion_cache('human_id', obj_class, mode="w"):
            with self.completion_cache('uuid', obj_class, mode="w"):

b) write my own RLock implementation in lockutils and use that in completion_cache.

c) use the RLock implementation from threading

Let me know the proper plan of attack here (or any other ideas, I'm new to Openstack so I'm not sure what the coding style should be here).

I also tried using lockutils.synchronize in this situation, but since there are 2  caches, I still see race conditions when using this.'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-10-30 20:09:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

You're right; if it takes crazy histrionics to use lockutils, then just using threading.RLock makes more sense."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-10-30 22:11:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I have to agree.  It may be worthwhile to ultimately add support for RLock-like semantics to lockutils, but that's way outside the scope of this patch, and using threading.RLock gets you there now without any histrionics‚Ä¶"}, {'account_id': 7774, 'date': '2013-10-30 22:35:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-11-04 09:31:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Adds locking to completion caches

Previously, completion caches were not thread-safe and multiple
threads could not make calls to python-novaclient simultaneously.
With locking, the completion caches are now thread-safe.

Closes-Bug: #1213958
Change-Id: I201c2ed0f1eb09b1c2a74de96119cbae9ed6f4b0

commit_message:
Stop testing deprecated command nova-manage instance_type

'nova-manage instance_type' was deprecated in Havana, and in order to
remove it in Icehouse we have to stop testing it in gate.

Related to Ieb3775e0a43084d00624f9e1d8b879c312e32b3c

Change-Id: I1ca490593d3a61424b0000c6d64a541b2c9bd42c

Remove unnecessary check from manager

removed because advanced check already implemented
in API.

[{'created': '2013-10-31 00:47:55.000000000', 'message': "add debugging for when changes-sinces fails

this test fails about once a month, even in it's current format.
It's hard to tell why at this point, so put in enough debugging so
that the next failure will let us understand what's going on.

Change-Id: I95b91faeea70536f6f4d5226cf6ebda20b93412d
"}]
commit_message:
add debugging for when changes-sinces fails

this test fails about once a month, even in it's current format.
It's hard to tell why at this point, so put in enough debugging so
that the next failure will let us understand what's going on.

Change-Id: I95b91faeea70536f6f4d5226cf6ebda20b93412d

Didn't test it, but one issue I found in Debian Sid, is that the newest e1000 driver doesn't support pxe boot (can be a bug or a feature), so it could hit ubuntu eventually."}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2013-10-31 17:44:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

13:40 <+ lifeless> slagle: we've had very bad issues with dhcp and virtio
13:41 <    slagle> lifeless: like what?  i was curious if there was a reason it 
                   wasn't used
13:41 <+ lifeless> slagle: packets going off into lala land
13:41 <+ lifeless> bad checksums [ and we're on an ovs datapath, so no fixup 
                   possible AFAIK ]
13:42 <+ lifeless> maddeningly it doesn't affect everyone
13:42 <    slagle> fair enough, if it's not stable enough to merge then we 
                   shouldn't
13:42 <    slagle> but, yea, it works ok for me
13:42 <    slagle> and the speedup is very impressive
13:42 <+ lifeless> we've changed a lot since then, it might work more broadly 
                   now, but I'd be more than a little worried
13:43 <    slagle> lifeless: maybe something configurable then? via environemnt 
                   variable?
13:43 <+ lifeless> slagle: yeah, that would be ok
13:44 <    slagle> k. will switch to WIP and update"}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-10-31 17:45:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

We've had major stability / reliability issues for contributors with virtio in the past - bad checksums on dhcp packets leading to them being ignored - that sort of thing.

It may be better now with the ovs bridge, but I'd like to be conservative: lets make this opt-in and then ask folk to give it a spin before we make it default."}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2013-10-31 17:45:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Going to update this patch to be configurable. Will continue to default to e1000 however.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2013-11-01 15:54:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-11-01 15:55:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-31 17:31:14.000000000', 'message': "Use the virtio libvirt driver instead of e1000.

Using the virtio libvirt driver for network interfaces results in much
better network performance between vm's.  Local testing indicates the
disk deployment by nova-baremetal-deploy-helper going from around 4
minutes to 1 minute after switching to virtio.  I did not do any more
extensive testing or gathering of hard data, but in general virtio is
just known to be quicker than e1000 emulation for the network
interface.

Change-Id: I4af35be6dd96fbd3201adac25a6e03bf5ecc712d
"}, {'created': '2013-11-01 15:54:58.000000000', 'message': "Expose option to set libvirt nic driver.

This commit adds an environment variable, $LIBVIRT_NIC_DRIVER, that
can be set to override the default e1000 driver.  Using the virtio
libvirt driver for network interfaces results in much better network
performance between vm's.  Local testing indicates the disk deployment
by nova-baremetal-deploy-helper going from around 4 minutes to 1
minute after switching to virtio.

virtio may be unstable on Ubuntu, see comments in
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=910619 for more details.

Change-Id: I4af35be6dd96fbd3201adac25a6e03bf5ecc712d
"}]
commit_message:
Expose option to set libvirt nic driver.

This commit adds an environment variable, $LIBVIRT_NIC_DRIVER, that
can be set to override the default e1000 driver.  Using the virtio
libvirt driver for network interfaces results in much better network
performance between vm's.  Local testing indicates the disk deployment
by nova-baremetal-deploy-helper going from around 4 minutes to 1
minute after switching to virtio.

virtio may be unstable on Ubuntu, see comments in
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=910619 for more details.

Change-Id: I4af35be6dd96fbd3201adac25a6e03bf5ecc712d

commit_message:
Add wrapper for keystone service catalog

This patch designed for receiving url of any
openstack service from keystone service catalog.
Examples: Ironic conductor and api are on different
hosts, conductor needs api url for deploy image,
get Glance service api for Ironic.

Change-Id: I3dc7475e10c7a464541be64d69ce97c41be7a650

Add design principles to docs

One of the things we should make clear is what Tempest is, and what
it isn't at any point in time. This should be up front and center
in our README

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-24 18:12:10.000000000', 'message': 'Adopt 0.1.8 as iso8601 minimum version

In the images api, we depend on iso8601 to parse some dates and times.
Recently, since version 0.1.4, python-iso8601 added support for a few
more formats, and we finally got some other issues nailed down by 0.1.8.
If end user switch from 0.1.8 back to 0.1.4 in the deployment, the image
api will lose support for certain datetime formats like YYYY-MM-DD
(where the time part is assumed to be all zeros). This obviously creates
a compatibility concern.

We were resolved to make glance compatible with both iso 0.1.4 and
0.1.8, but it appears that to do so requires essentially reimplementing
a large swath of iso8601 0.1.8 in glance itself.

Fixes bug: 1242501

Change-Id: Iece0116d3c412216251e2d7fbffe10bfe2c1c789
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Adopt 0.1.8 as iso8601 minimum version

In the images api, we depend on iso8601 to parse some dates and times.
Recently, since version 0.1.4, python-iso8601 added support for a few
more formats, and we finally got some other issues nailed down by 0.1.8.
If end user switch from 0.1.8 back to 0.1.4 in the deployment, the image
api will lose support for certain datetime formats like YYYY-MM-DD
(where the time part is assumed to be all zeros). This obviously creates
a compatibility concern.

We were resolved to make glance compatible with both iso 0.1.4 and
0.1.8, but it appears that to do so requires essentially reimplementing
a large swath of iso8601 0.1.8 in glance itself.

Fixes bug: 1242501

Change-Id: Iece0116d3c412216251e2d7fbffe10bfe2c1c789
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Add configurable timeout for ovs-vsctl

Enables the user to update the timeout. The default is 2.
0 will wait forever.

Change-Id: I048ccf0133843a1580e18e570a0d5194f1f41635
Closes-Bug: #1239889

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-19 08:09:33.000000000', 'message': 'glance-replicator: decode metadata dictionary to str recursively

bug 1213822

When syncing images across different datacenters via glance-relicator,
some images' metadatas are always updated to the slave glance, even it
has already been synced before. The problem lies in here:

log output:
metadata diff -- value differs for key properties: master "{u'vm_mode': u'hvm'}"
vs slave "{'vm_mode': 'hvm'}"
... metadata has changed

......

On doing image compare, glance-replicator gets image metadatas from both master
and slave. Then it try to do a 'diff' for these metadatas. If the metadatas are
different according to the diff result, metadatas from the master are updated
to the slave. The _dict_diff() function are responsible for doing metadate
comparing. It translate the metadata dictionary to str before doing compare, but
it doesn't handle the situation when metadata dictionary has sub-dictionary.

This patch fixes this problem by decoding metadata dictionary to str recursively
before doing diff, so that sub-dictionary items could also be translated to str.

Change-Id: Ibdcb0c3e770495d8847d57a03b73e8f20b0337de
'}, {'created': '2013-08-19 08:11:55.000000000', 'message': 'glance-replicator: decode metadata dictionary to str recursively

bug 1213822

When syncing images across different datacenters via glance-relicator,
some images' metadatas are always updated to the slave glance, even it
has already been synced before. The problem lies in here:

log output:
metadata diff -- value differs for key properties: master "{u'vm_mode': u'hvm'}"
vs slave "{'vm_mode': 'hvm'}"
... metadata has changed

On doing image compare, glance-replicator gets image metadatas from both master
and slave. Then it try to do a 'diff' for these metadatas. If the metadatas are
different according to the diff result, metadatas from the master are updated
to the slave. The _dict_diff() function are responsible for doing metadate
comparing. It translate the metadata dictionary to str before doing compare, but
it doesn't handle the situation when metadata dictionary has sub-dictionary.

This patch fixes this problem by decoding metadata dictionary to str recursively
before doing diff, so that sub-dictionary items could also be translated to str.

Change-Id: Ibdcb0c3e770495d8847d57a03b73e8f20b0337de

On doing image compare, glance-replicator gets image metadatas from both master
and slave. Then it try to do a 'diff' for these metadatas. If the metadatas are
different according to the diff result, metadatas from the master are updated
to the slave. The _dict_diff() function are responsible for doing metadate
comparing. It translate the metadata dictionary to str before doing compare, but
it doesn't handle the situation when metadata dictionary has sub-dictionary.

This patch fixes this problem by decoding metadata dictionary to str recursively
before doing diff, so that sub-dictionary items could also be translated to str.

commit_message:
glance-replicator: decode metadata dictionary to unicode recursively

When syncing images across different datacenters via glance-relicator,
some images' metadatas are always updated to the slave glance, even it
has already been synced before. The problem lies in here:

log output:
metadata diff -- value differs for key properties: master "{u'vm_mode': u'hvm'}"
vs slave "{'vm_mode': 'hvm'}"
... metadata has changed

On doing image compare, glance-replicator gets image metadatas from both master
and slave. Then it try to do a 'diff' for these metadatas. If the metadatas are
different according to the diff result, metadatas from the master are updated
to the slave. The _dict_diff() function are responsible for doing metadata
comparing. It translate the metadata dictionary to str before doing compare, but
it doesn't handle the situation when metadata dictionary has sub-dictionary.

This patch fixes this problem by decoding metadata dictionary to unicode recursively
before doing diff, so that sub-dictionary items could also be translated to unicode.

bug 1213822

Change-Id: Ibdcb0c3e770495d8847d57a03b73e8f20b0337de

'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-09-11 03:38:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I *think* since this is an internal API we're actually *following* the robustness principle by enforcing strict requirements on *internal* messages.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robustness_principle

That said, I'm probably not the only person who has some lazy code laying around somewhere that this change will break because I'm talking directly to backend servers and somewhere I just call "putheader('x-timestamp', time.time())" and end up sending '1378868342.82' instead of '1378868342.824411'

But I guess that's the point... keep those lazy mis-behaving agents in check.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-09-12 00:56:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-12 01:25:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Works for me
