revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-29 12:32:53.000000000', 'message': 'Externalisation of heat template

Reasons: preparing trove to support multi-datastores
Changes: template loading, heat-support update
This code piece refactors the earlier code of instance creation
using heat.

- Configuration tempaltes stored at trove/templates/configuration
- Heat templates are stored in trove/templates/heat
- One template per datastore type
- New parameter - ImageId
- Removed SSH key parameter

commit_message:
Externalisation of heat template

Reasons: preparing trove to support multi-datastores
Changes: template loading, heat-support update
This code piece refactors the earlier code of instance creation
using heat.

- Configuration tempaltes stored at trove/templates/configuration
- Heat templates are stored in trove/templates/heat
- One template per datastore type
- New parameter - ImageId
- Removed SSH key parameter
- All resources are updated according to available OS resources
  (for more details please visit heat repository).

For each datastore  we have a unique template file
<datastore_type>.heat.template

Change-Id: If4f185542076e578c5148615cac2cc2a03cf9dbb
Implements: blueprint provide-custom-heat-templates-for-each-service-in-trove

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-04-09 10:09:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I think this is an interesting idea, but I'm not sure I like this implementation.

The nova.manager is already using a DynamicLoopingCall. If each periodic task optionally returned how long it wanted to wait before being called, then that could just be fed into the manager's view of what needs to run when and how long to sleep to make that happen. Take a look at nova.manager.Manager.periodic_tasks to see what I mean."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-04-09 17:18:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 25.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-09 17:39:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 25: Doesn't seem to work

"}, {'account_id': 4468, 'date': '2013-04-11 08:33:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 33: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-04-11 11:27:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 33: Do not merge

I'm not convinced ... this is a large patch and I'm not sure there is enough benefit to justify it.  Based on the commit message, this is trying to optimize out cases where periodic tasks do nothing.  If they are doing nothing, why do we need to do all this work to optimize them?"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-04-11 15:31:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 33:

@Russell,

The idea was that periodic tasks even when they appear to do nothing (no changes) that when they run, often they make conductor calls to retrieve empty lists, call out to drivers which will just repeatly say not implemented.... All cases where we have to ask why are we running at the same periodic interval (or running this periodic task at all in the first place). This patch was meant to allow the periodic task to have the capabiltiy to adjust its own timer (self-feedback on how often it runs). Seeing that the whole decorator mechanism makes this hard to accomplish (decorators are static things) this change starts to move toward a direction where tasks have the capability to alter there own timing... This will likely save db calls/mq calls in clouds with idle instances...

Does that make sense?'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-04-11 15:37:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 33:

And more info, periodic tasks may initially do nothing, but when an instance request (or other request) comes in that may force the task to do work occurs, then whatever adjustments need to be undone, thats why u see the reset_timers decorator being added. Otherwise how would a task that has said it doesn't need to run until someday in the future be altered to run at there original rate when a new instance has been created (since said task could not have predicted the future when that instance request would have arrived)."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-04-19 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 33: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-04-19 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 33:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-06 02:04:01.000000000', 'message': "Make compute periodic tasks have exponential backoff.

When a periodic task runs and it actually doesn't do anything,
either due to no data (aka nothing for the db) we shouldn't run it
again at the same interval to just retrieve nothing again but
instead we should expand the interval. When it refires and new
data arrives (instead of being empty) then we will reset to the initial
duration.

Change-Id: Idc3b5b99b0dfd399f8682fcf7b31e50109a5e1a0

"}, {'created': '2013-04-06 20:53:52.000000000', 'message': "Make compute periodic tasks intervals smart.

When a periodic task runs and it actually doesn't do anything,
either due to no data (aka nothing from the db/conductor) or due to not
having a underlying implementing driver we should not run it
again at the same interval to just retrieve nothing again but
instead we should expand the interval, or just disable the periodic task
to begin with. If a event comes in that should reset the interval,
like a compute 'boot' then we will reset to the initial duration (iff
not already disabled due to the underlying driver not implementing said
feature in the first place).

Fixes bug 1165275

Change-Id: Idc3b5b99b0dfd399f8682fcf7b31e50109a5e1a0

either due to no data (aka nothing from the db/conductor) or due to not

again at the same interval to just retrieve nothing again but
instead we should expand the interval, or just disable the periodic task
to begin with. If a event comes in that should reset the interval,
like a compute 'boot' then we will reset to the initial duration (iff
not already disabled due to the underlying driver not implementing said

either due to no data (aka nothing from the db/conductor) or due to not

again at the same interval to just retrieve nothing again but
instead we should expand the interval, or just disable the periodic task

like a compute 'boot' then we will reset to the initial duration (iff
not already disabled due to the underlying driver not implementing said
feature in the first place).

Fixes bug 1165275

commit_message:
Make compute periodic tasks intervals smart.

When a periodic task runs and it actually doesn't do anything,
either due to no data (aka nothing from the db/conductor) or due to not
having a underlying implementing driver we should not run it
again at the same interval to just retrieve nothing again but
instead we should expand the interval, or just disable the periodic task
to begin with. If a event comes in that should reset the interval,
like a compute 'boot' then we will reset to the initial duration (iff
not already disabled due to the underlying driver not implementing said
feature in the first place).

Fixes bug 1165275

DocImpact

Change-Id: Idc3b5b99b0dfd399f8682fcf7b31e50109a5e1a0

The license is here:

http://opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php

but if I try to apply it it fails in the jenkins/ci steps because it's not an apache license.  Is that a valid failure?  

An no - the code for SSH support is transparent.  If the vanilla plugin developers need any HTTP interaction during installation they'll have to code that (I don't believe that's the case)."}, {'account_id': 7737, 'date': '2013-10-29 22:35:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7555, 'date': '2013-10-30 13:13:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Re license - Ok, we cannot put an ASL stamp on the LRU code. Given https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/LegalIssuesFAQ - my preference is to either 0) find an ASLd implementation, or 1) remove the code, or 2) demonstrate we will not introduce the need to distribute attribution notices (do other projects already?)

Re feature - To keep the consumption of Savanna straight forward for our users we should keep the plugins up to a minimum level of feature support. Since we haven't discussed this much yet, I'll +1 if you simply record, in some fashion of your choice, that this feature gap exists between the HDP and Vanilla plugins."}, {'account_id': 7737, 'date': '2013-10-30 15:29:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-30 15:29:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Enable network operations over neutron private nets

Enables communication between the savanna api server and the spawned
VMs over the specific network namespace associated with the selected
network.  The SSH and HTTP communication will be conducted over
netcat based subprocesses.  This feature is enabled when the
configuration indicates that neutron networking is enabled while
the use of public IPs is set to false.

Implements blueprint neutron-private-net-provisioning

Change-Id: I61d61a7ef6eccb04274549883dde489641d1da9b

(1 inline comment)

Apart from Ben's comment, looks good to me too

I worry a little about backwards compat here ... is there any predictable IOErrors that people could have written code explicitly to handle under the knowledge that ConfigFilesNotFoundError would be raised?

And, yes, now that I look ... in nova-manage:

    try:
        config.parse_args(sys.argv)
        logging.setup("nova")
    except cfg.ConfigFilesNotFoundError:
        cfgfile = CONF.config_file[-1] if CONF.config_file else None
        if cfgfile and not os.access(cfgfile, os.R_OK):
            st = os.stat(cfgfile)
            print(_("Could not read %s. Re-running with sudo") % cfgfile)
            try:
                os.execvp('sudo', ['sudo', '-u', '#%s' % st.st_uid] + sys.argv)
            except Exception:
                print(_('sudo failed, continuing as if nothing happened'))

        print(_('Please re-run nova-manage as root.'))
        return(2)

that's pretty bizarre behaviour, but I don't want to break it

So ... let's continue raising ConfigFilesNotFound for EPERM too'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-10-30 07:12:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Oh, and yes - "not found" doesn't describe "don't have permission to read" very well ... so we could do a follow-up change to add an e.g. ConfigFilesPermissionDenied subclass of ConfigFilesNotFound'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-10-30 07:17:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Hey Mark,

> So ... let's continue raising ConfigFilesNotFound for EPERM too

I'm looking at that part of the nova code. Did you mean EACCES, instead of EPERM? EACCES is raised if the user has no permission to access the file; EPERM is 'Operation not permitted' (the cause of which is not entirely clear to me). Which one should we consume? Both?

> Oh, and yes - "not found" doesn't describe "don't have permission to read" very well ... so we could do a follow-up change to add an e.g. ConfigFilesPermissionDenied subclass of ConfigFilesNotFound

Once the EACCES/EPERM detail is clear, I'll amend the code and write a bug to suggest this change.'}, {'account_id': 9166, 'date': '2013-10-30 10:16:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Restored'}, {'account_id': 9166, 'date': '2013-10-30 10:16:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-10-30 10:17:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-29 12:38:27.000000000', 'message': "ConfigParser no longer obscures IOErrors

ConfigParser no longer interprets all IOErrors as 'No such file or
directory'. The current behavior does not change: 'No such file'
IOErrors are swallowed and dealt with elsewhere. The fundamental change
here is that other types of IOErrors are re-raised. (Before this, all
types of IOErrors--including, for example, 'Too many open files'--were
treated as 'No such file', which is obviously not correct.)

Also added a test to exercise the case where IOErrors are reraised. The
'No such file' case is already covered by existing tests.

Change-Id: I10e4e5965212737a19f4f17153143f62b5c0c83e
Closes-Bug: #1244674

all IOErrors as 'No such file or directory', and instead allows these
errors to propagate normally. The current behavior with respect to
ConfigOpts does not change for IOErrors indicating 'No such file' or
'Permission denied'.

Also added a test to exercise the case where IOErrors are reraised. The

commit_message:
Fix to make ConfigOpts no longer obscure IOErrors

This changes ConfigParser._parse_file such that it no longer interprets
all IOErrors as 'No such file or directory', and instead allows these
errors to propagate normally. The current behavior with respect to
ConfigOpts does not change for IOErrors indicating 'No such file' or
'Permission denied'.

Also added a test to exercise the case where IOErrors are reraised. The
'No such file' case is already covered by existing tests.

Change-Id: I10e4e5965212737a19f4f17153143f62b5c0c83e
Closes-Bug: #1244674

[{'created': '2013-10-09 17:38:21.000000000', 'message': 'Contributing standalone tools

They may be useful to other Designate users/devs.

They are:

* designatehooks.py: Intended to run as a daemon, consume Central's MQ
notifications, and act on them. Developed to command a remote NSD 4 slave
server, efforts were made to keep it modular end extensible, so it can be used
to "hook" any external system into Designate.

* zoneextractor.py: Intended to help the client-side of the new zone import API,
it takes a BIND9 named.conf and writes out or prints a zonefile for every
configured master zone. Said zonefile can then be curled or otherwise submitted
to the zonefile import API.

Change-Id: Ibc15639771da52e678be067ec4474bcbcc2f0865

'}, {'created': '2013-10-11 21:46:16.000000000', 'message': 'Contributing standalone tools

They may be useful to other Designate users/devs.

They are:

* designatehooks.py: Module that provides classes to consume MQ
notifications and pass them off to a handler. A base handler and a
handler for NSD 4 are provided.

* nsdhooks.py: Runnable example using the classes from
designatehooks.py to control a remote NSD 4 slave.

* zoneextractor.py: Intended to help the client-side of the new zone
import API, it takes a BIND9 named.conf and writes out or prints a
zonefile for every configured master zone. Said zonefile can then be
curled or otherwise submitted to the zonefile import API.

Change-Id: Ibc15639771da52e678be067ec4474bcbcc2f0865
'}, {'created': '2013-10-24 13:46:18.000000000', 'message': 'Zoneextractor tool

zoneextractor.py helps on the client-side of the new zone
import API. It takes a BIND9 named.conf and writes out or prints a
zonefile for every configured master zone. Said zonefile can then be
curled or otherwise submitted to the zonefile import API.

Change-Id: Ibc15639771da52e678be067ec4474bcbcc2f0865
'}]
commit_message:
Zoneextractor tool

zoneextractor.py helps on the client-side of the new zone
import API. It takes a BIND9 named.conf and writes out or prints a
zonefile for every configured master zone. Said zonefile can then be
curled or otherwise submitted to the zonefile import API.

Change-Id: Ibc15639771da52e678be067ec4474bcbcc2f0865

[{'created': '2013-11-01 13:06:18.000000000', 'message': "Fix ZeroDivisionError in ratio calculation

Now that the script counts up +A, it's possible for someone to be in
the list with a total of 0 reviews (sum of -2,-1,+1,+2 votes), causing
this line to blow up.

Change-Id: Ia27226682673dce603a9a9a181234400d7ac4a16
"}]
commit_message:
Fix ZeroDivisionError in ratio calculation

Now that the script counts up +A, it's possible for someone to be in
the list with a total of 0 reviews (sum of -2,-1,+1,+2 votes), causing
this line to blow up.

Change-Id: Ia27226682673dce603a9a9a181234400d7ac4a16

commit_message:
Resolved issue with checkbox layouts

Fixed bug #1242656
Cherry-picked from release-0.3

Change-Id: I26cb8d8b6d22a212940ed0af65d195319d8596ae
